Original: HISTORY:,  The patient is a 52-year-old female with a past medical history of diet-controlled diabetes, diffuse arthritis, plantar fasciitis, and muscle cramps who presents with a few-month history of numbness in both big toes and up the lateral aspect of both calves.  Symptoms worsened considerable about a month ago.  This normally occurs after being on her feet for any length of time.  She was started on amitriptyline and this has significantly improved her symptoms.  She is almost asymptomatic at present.  She dose complain of longstanding low back pain, but no pain that radiates from her back into her legs.  She has had no associated weakness.,On brief examination, straight leg raising is normal.  The patient is obese.  There is mild decreased vibration and light touch in distal lower extremities.  Strength is full and symmetric.  Deep tendon reflexes at the knees are 2+ and symmetric and absent at the ankles.,NERVE CONDUCTION STUDIES: , Bilateral sural sensory responses are absent.  Bilateral superficial sensory responses are present, but mildly reduced.  The right radial sensory response is normal.  The right common peroneal and tibial motor responses are normal.  Bilateral H-reflexes are absent.,NEEDLE EMG:,  Needle EMG was performed on the right leg and lumbosacral paraspinal muscles and the left tibialis posterior using a concentric disposable needle.  It revealed increased insertional activity in the right tibialis posterior muscle with signs of mild chronic denervation in bilateral peroneus longus muscles and the right tibialis posterior muscle.  Lumbar paraspinals were attempted, but were too painful to get a good assessment.,IMPRESSION:  ,This electrical study is abnormal.  It reveals the following:,1.  A very mild, purely sensory length-dependent peripheral neuropathy.,2.  Mild bilateral L5 nerve root irritation.  There is no evidence of active radiculopathy.,Based on the patient's history and exam, her new symptoms are consistent with mild bilateral L5 radiculopathies.  Symptoms have almost completely resolved over the last month since starting Elavil.  I would recommend MRI of the lumbosacral spine if symptoms return.  With respect to the mild neuropathy, this is probably related to her mild glucose intolerance/early diabetes.  However, I would recommend a workup for other causes to include the following:  Fasting blood sugar, HbA1c, ESR, RPR, TSH, B12, serum protein electrophoresis and Lyme titer.
Synthetic:
HISTORY: A 52-year-old woman with a medical background of diet-managed diabetes, widespread arthritis, plantar fasciitis, and muscle cramps presents with a several-month history of numbness in both big toes and along the outer sides of both calves. Her symptoms significantly worsened about a month ago, typically emerging after prolonged standing. She began amitriptyline treatment, which has notably improved her condition, leaving her nearly symptom-free now. She reports chronic low back pain but denies any pain radiating from her back to her legs. She has experienced no associated weakness. On a brief examination, straight leg raising tests are normal. The patient is overweight. There is a slight reduction in vibration and light touch sensation in the lower extremities. Muscle strength is full and symmetric. Knee reflexes are 2+ and symmetric, while ankle reflexes are absent.

NERVE CONDUCTION STUDIES: Sural sensory responses are absent bilaterally. Superficial sensory responses are present but moderately diminished. The sensory response in the right radial is normal. Motor responses in the right common peroneal and tibial nerves are normal. Bilateral H-reflexes are absent.

NEEDLE EMG: Conducted on the right leg, lumbosacral paraspinal muscles, and left tibialis posterior with a concentric disposable needle, the EMG showed increased insertional activity in the right tibialis posterior muscle and signs of mild chronic denervation in both peroneus longus muscles and the right tibialis posterior muscle. Attempts to assess the lumbar paraspinals were made, but they were too painful to evaluate effectively.

IMPRESSION: This electrical study is abnormal, indicating the following: 1. A very mild, purely sensory length-dependent peripheral neuropathy. 2. Mild bilateral L5 nerve root irritation without active radiculopathy. Considering the patient's history and examination, her recent symptoms align with mild bilateral L5 radiculopathies. Symptoms have almost entirely resolved over the past month since starting Elavil. An MRI of the lumbosacral spine is advised if symptoms recur. Regarding the mild neuropathy, it is likely linked to her mild glucose intolerance/early diabetes, but further investigation for other causes is recommended, including fasting blood sugar, HbA1c, ESR, RPR, TSH, B12, serum protein electrophoresis, and Lyme titer.

Lumbar paraspinals were attempted, but were too painful to get a good assessment., IMPRESSION: , This electrical study is abnormal. It reveals the following:, 1. A very mild, purely sensory length-dependent peripheral neuropathy., 2. Mild bilateral L5 nerve root irritation. There is no evidence of active radiculopathy., Based on the patient's history and exam, her new symptoms are consistent with mild bilateral L5 radiculopathies. However, I would recommend a workup for other causes to include the following: Fasting blood sugar, HbA1c, ESR, RPR, TSH, B12, serum protein electrophoresis, and Lyme titer.

Original: REASON FOR REFERRAL: , Ms. A is a 60-year-old African-American female with 12 years of education who was referred for neuropsychological evaluation by Dr. X after she demonstrated mild cognitive deficits on a neuropsychological screening evaluation during a followup appointment with him for stroke in July.  A comprehensive evaluation was requested to assess current cognitive functioning and assist with diagnostic decisions and treatment planning.,RELEVANT BACKGROUND INFORMATION:,  Historical information was obtained from a review of available medical records and clinical interview with Ms. A.  A summary of pertinent information is presented below.  Please refer to the patient's medical chart for a more complete history.,HISTORY OF PRESENTING PROBLEM:,  Ms. A presented to the ABC Hospital emergency department on 07/26/2009 reporting that after she had woken up that morning she noticed numbness and weakness in her left hand, slurred speech, and left facial droop.  Neurological evaluation with Dr. X confirmed left hemiparesis.  Brain CT showed no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage or mass effect and that she received TPA and had moderate improvement in left-sided weakness.  These symptoms were thought to be due to a right middle cerebral artery stroke.  She was transferred to the ICU for monitoring.  Ultrasound of the carotids showed 20% to 30% stenosis of the right ICA and 0% to 19% stenosis of the left ICA.  On 07/29/2009, she was admitted for acute inpatient rehabilitation for the treatment of residual functional deficits of her acute ischemic right MCA/CVA.  At discharge on 08/06/2009, she was mainly on supervision for all ADLs and walking with a rolling walker, but tolerating increased ambulation with a cane.  She was discharged home with recommendations for outpatient physical therapy.  She returned to the Sinai ER on 08/2009/2009 due to reported left arm pain, numbness, and weakness, which lasted 10 to 15 minutes and she reported that it felt "just like the stroke."  Brain CT on 08/2009/2009 was read as showing "mild chronic microvascular ischemic change of deep white matter," but no acute or significant interval change compared to her previous scan.  Neurological examination with Dr. Y was within normal limits, but she was admitted for a more extensive workup.  Due to left arm pain an ultrasound was completed on her left upper extremity, but it did not show deep vein thrombosis.,Followup CT on 08/10/2009 showed no significant interval change.  MRI could not be completed due to the patient's weight.  She was discharged on 08/11/2009 in stable condition after it was determined that this event was not neurological in origin; however, note that Ms. A referred to this as a second stroke.,Ms. A presented for a followup outpatient neurological evaluation with Dr. X on 09/22/2009, at which time a brief neuropsychological screening was also conducted.  She demonstrated significant impairments in confrontation naming, abstract verbal reasoning, and visual and verbal memory and thus a more comprehensive evaluation was suggested due to her intent to return to her full-time work duty.  During the current interview, Ms. A reported that she noticed mild memory problems including some difficultly remembering conversations, events, and at times forgetting to take her medications.  She also reported mild difficulty finding words in conversation, solving novel problems and tasks (e.g. difficulty learning to use her camcorder), but overall denied significant cognitive deficits in attention, concentration, language or other areas of cognitive functioning.  When asked about her return to work, she said that she was still on light duty due to limited physical activity because of residual left leg weakness.  She reported that no one had indicated to her that she appeared less capable of performing her job duties, but said that she was also receiving fewer files to process and enter data into the computer at the Social Security Agency that she works at.  Note also that she had some difficulty explaining exactly what her job involved.  She also reported having problems falling asleep at work and that she is working full-time although on light duty.,OTHER MEDICAL HISTORY:  ,As mentioned, Ms. A continues to have some residual left leg weakness and continues to use a rolling walker for ambulation, but she reported that her motor functioning had improved significantly.  She was diagnosed with sleep apnea approximately two years ago and was recently counseled by Dr. X on the need to use her CPAP because she indicated she never used it at night.  She reported that since her appointment with Dr. X, she has been using it "every other night."  When asked about daytime fatigue, Ms. A initially denied that she was having any difficulties, but repeatedly indicated that she was falling asleep at work and thought that it was due to looking at a computer screen.  She reported at times "snoring" and forgetting where she is at and said that a supervisor offered to give her coffee at one point.  She receives approximately two to five hours of sleep per night.  Other current untreated risk factors include obesity and hypercholesterolemia.  Her medical history is also significant for hypertension, asthma, abdominal adenocarcinoma status post hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, colonic benign polyps status post resection, benign lesions of the breast status post lumpectomy, and deep vein thrombosis in the left lower extremity status post six months of anticoagulation (which she had discontinued just prior to her stroke).,CURRENT MEDICATIONS: , Aspirin 81 mg daily, Colace 100 mg b.i.d., Lipitor 80 mg daily, and albuterol MDI p.r.n.,SUBSTANCE USE:,  Ms. A denied drinking alcohol or using illicit drugs.  She used to smoke a pack of cigarettes per day, but quit five to six years ago.,FAMILY MEDICAL HISTORY: , Ms. A had difficulty providing information on familial medical history.  She reported that her mother died three to four years ago from lung cancer.  Her father has gout and blood clots.  Siblings have reportedly been treated for asthma and GI tumors.  She was unsure of familial history of other conditions such as hypertension, high cholesterol, stroke, etc.,SOCIAL HISTORY: , Ms. A completed high school degree.  She reported that she primarily obtained B's and C's in school.  She received some tutoring for algebra in middle school, but denied ever having been held back a grade failing any classes or having any problems with attention or hyperactivity.,She currently works for the Social Security Administration in data processing.  As mentioned, she has returned to full-time work, but continues to perform only light duties due to her physical condition.  She is now living on her own.  She has never driven.  She reported that she continues to perform ADLs independently such as cooking and cleaning.  She lost her husband in 2005 and has three adult daughters.  She previously reported some concerns that her children wanted her to move into assisted living, but she did not discuss that during this current evaluation.  She also reported number of other family members who had recently passed away.  She has returned to activities she enjoys such as quire, knitting, and cooking and plans to go on a cruise to the Bahamas at the end of October.,PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY: , Ms. A did not report a history of psychological or psychiatric treatment.  She reported that her current mood was good, but did describe some anxiety and nervousness about various issues such as her return to work, her upcoming trip, and other events.  She reported that this only "comes and goes.",TASKS ADMINISTERED:,Clinical Interview,Adult History Questionnaire,Wechsler Test of Adult Reading (WTAR),Mini Mental Status Exam (MMSE),Cognistat Neurobehavioral Cognitive Status Examination,Repeatable Battery for the Assessment of Neuropsychological Status (RBANS; Form XX),Mattis Dementia Rating Scale, 2nd Edition (DRS-2),Neuropsychological Assessment Battery (NAB),Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale, Third Edition (WAIS-III),Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale, Fourth Edition (WAIS-IV),Wechsler Abbreviated Scale of Intelligence (WASI),Test of Variables of Attention (TOVA),Auditory Consonant Trigrams (ACT),Paced Auditory Serial Addition Test (PASAT),Ruff 2 & 7 Selective Attention Test,Symbol Digit Modalities Test (SDMT),Multilingual Aphasia Examination, Second Edition (MAE-II),  Token Test,  Sentence Repetition,  Visual Naming,  Controlled Oral Word Association,  Spelling Test,  Aural Comprehension,  Reading Comprehension,Boston Naming Test, Second Edition (BNT-2),Animal Naming Test
Synthetic: REASON FOR REFERRAL: Ms. A, a 60-year-old African-American woman with a 12th-grade education, was referred for a neuropsychological assessment by Dr. X following mild cognitive difficulties observed during a neuropsychological screening evaluation at a follow-up appointment for her stroke in July. A thorough evaluation was needed to assess her current cognitive state and support diagnostic and treatment planning decisions. RELEVANT BACKGROUND INFORMATION: Historical details were gathered from Ms. A's medical records and a clinical interview, summarized below. For a complete history, please consult the patient's medical chart. HISTORY OF PRESENTING PROBLEM: On July 26, 2009, Ms. A went to the ABC Hospital emergency department, experiencing numbness and weakness in her left hand, slurred speech, and drooping on the left side of her face upon waking. Dr. X's neurological exam confirmed left hemiparesis. A brain CT showed no intracranial hemorrhage or mass effect, and she was administered TPA, which moderately improved her left-sided weakness. These symptoms were attributed to a stroke in the right middle cerebral artery. She was monitored in the ICU, and an ultrasound revealed 20% to 30% stenosis in the right ICA and 0% to 19% stenosis in the left ICA. On July 29, 2009, she was admitted for acute inpatient rehabilitation to treat residual functional deficits from her acute ischemic right MCA/CVA. By discharge on August 6, 2009, she required supervision for all ADLs and was walking with a rolling walker, though she could tolerate increased ambulation with a cane. She was sent home with recommendations for outpatient physical therapy. Ms. A returned to the Sinai ER in August 2009 with left arm pain, numbness, and weakness lasting 10 to 15 minutes, describing it as feeling "just like the stroke." An August 2009 brain CT indicated "mild chronic microvascular ischemic change of deep white matter," but no acute or significant changes compared to her previous scan. Neurological examination with Dr. Y was normal, but she was admitted for further investigation. An ultrasound of her left upper extremity showed no deep vein thrombosis despite her left arm pain. A follow-up CT on August 10, 2009, showed no significant changes, and an MRI couldn't be performed due to her weight. She was discharged on August 11, 2009, in stable condition after it was determined that the event was not neurological in origin, although Ms. A referred to this as a second stroke. Ms. A visited Dr. X for an outpatient neurological follow-up on September 22, 2009, where a brief neuropsychological screening was conducted. She showed significant impairments in naming confrontation, abstract verbal reasoning, and visual and verbal memory, prompting a suggestion for a more comprehensive evaluation due to her plans to resume full-time work. During the current interview, Ms. A reported mild memory issues, such as difficulty remembering conversations and events and occasionally forgetting to take her medications. She also noted mild word-finding difficulty in conversation and challenges in solving new problems and tasks (such as learning to use her camcorder) but generally denied significant cognitive deficits in attention, concentration, language, or other areas. When asked about her return to work, she stated she was still on light duty due to limited physical activity from residual left leg weakness. She claimed no one had suggested she was less capable of performing her job duties, although she noticed receiving fewer files to process and enter into the computer at her workplace, the Social Security Agency. She had some difficulty explaining her job responsibilities and reported falling asleep at work, despite her full-time light-duty status. OTHER MEDICAL HISTORY: Ms. A continues to experience some residual left leg weakness and uses a rolling walker for mobility, although her motor function has significantly improved. Diagnosed with sleep apnea about two years ago, she was recently advised by Dr. X to use her CPAP machine, which she admitted to using "every other night" since her appointment. While Ms. A initially denied daytime fatigue, she later acknowledged falling asleep at work, attributing it to looking at a computer screen. She mentioned "snoring" and forgetting her whereabouts, with a supervisor once offering her coffee. Her sleep averages two to five hours per night. Other untreated risk factors include obesity and hypercholesterolemia. Her medical history also includes hypertension, asthma, abdominal adenocarcinoma status post-hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, colonic benign polyps status post-resection, benign breast lesions status post-lumpectomy, and deep vein thrombosis in the left lower extremity status post-six months of anticoagulation, discontinued just before her stroke. CURRENT MEDICATIONS: Aspirin 81 mg daily, Colace 100 mg twice daily, Lipitor 80 mg daily, and albuterol MDI as needed. SUBSTANCE USE: Ms. A denied alcohol or illicit drug use. She previously smoked a pack of cigarettes daily but quit five to six years ago. FAMILY MEDICAL HISTORY: Ms. A struggled to provide familial medical history, noting her mother died three to four years ago from lung cancer. Her father has gout and blood clots, and siblings reportedly have asthma and GI tumors. She was unsure about familial hypertension, high cholesterol, stroke, etc. SOCIAL HISTORY: Ms. A completed high school with B's and C's, received tutoring in middle school algebra, and never repeated a grade or failed, nor had attention or hyperactivity issues. She works at the Social Security Administration in data processing, returned to full-time light-duty work due to her physical condition, lives independently, never drove, and continues performing ADLs like cooking and cleaning. Widowed in 2005 with three adult daughters, she previously expressed concerns about her children wanting her to move to assisted living, but this wasn't discussed during the current evaluation. She mentioned several recent family deaths and resumed hobbies like choir, knitting, and cooking, with plans for a Bahamas cruise at the end of October. PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY: Ms. A reported no psychological or psychiatric treatment history, describing her current mood as good but experiencing occasional anxiety and nervousness about returning to work, her upcoming trip, and other events, which she said "comes and goes." TASKS ADMINISTERED: Clinical Interview, Adult History Questionnaire, Wechsler Test of Adult Reading (WTAR), Mini Mental Status Exam (MMSE), Cognistat Neurobehavioral Cognitive Status Examination, Repeatable Battery for the Assessment of Neuropsychological Status (RBANS; Form XX), Mattis Dementia Rating Scale, 2nd Edition (DRS-2), Neuropsychological Assessment Battery (NAB), Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale, Third Edition (WAIS-III), Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale, Fourth Edition (WAIS-IV), Wechsler Abbreviated Scale of Intelligence (WASI), Test of Variables of Attention (TOVA), Auditory Consonant Trigrams (ACT), Paced Auditory Serial Addition Test (PASAT), Ruff 2 & 7 Selective Attention Test, Symbol Digit Modalities Test (SDMT), Multilingual Aphasia Examination, Second Edition (MAE-II), Token Test, Sentence Repetition, Visual Naming, Controlled Oral Word Association, Spelling Test, Aural Comprehension, Reading Comprehension, Boston Naming Test, Second Edition (BNT-2), Animal Naming Test.

She reported that no one had indicated to her that she appeared less capable of performing her job duties, but said that she was also receiving fewer files to process and enter data into the computer at the Social Security Agency that she works at. Note also that she had some difficulty explaining exactly what her job involved. She also reported having problems falling asleep at work and that she is working full-time although on light duty.

OTHER MEDICAL HISTORY: As mentioned, Ms. A continues to have some residual left leg weakness and continues to use a rolling walker for ambulation, but she reported that her motor functioning had improved significantly. She was diagnosed with sleep apnea approximately two years ago and was recently counseled by Dr. X on the need to use her CPAP because she indicated she never used it at night. She reported that since her appointment with Dr. X, she has been using it "every other night." When asked about daytime fatigue, Ms. A initially denied that she was having any difficulties, but repeatedly indicated that she was falling asleep at work and thought that it was due to looking at a computer screen. She reported at times "snoring" and forgetting where she is at and said that a supervisor offered to give her coffee at one point. She receives approximately two to five hours of sleep per night. Other current untreated risk factors include obesity and hypercholesterolemia. Her medical history is also significant for hypertension, asthma, abdominal adenocarcinoma status post hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, colonic benign polyps status post resection, benign lesions of the breast status post lumpectomy, and deep vein thrombosis in the left lower extremity status post six months of anticoagulation (which she had discontinued just prior to her stroke).

CURRENT MEDICATIONS: Aspirin 81 mg daily, Colace 100 mg b.i.d., Lipitor 80 mg daily, and albuterol MDI p.r.n.

SUBSTANCE USE: Ms. A denied drinking alcohol or using illicit drugs. She used to smoke a pack of cigarettes per day, but quit five to six years ago.

FAMILY MEDICAL HISTORY: Ms. A had difficulty providing information on familial medical history. She reported that her mother died three to four years ago from lung cancer. Her father has gout and blood clots. Siblings have reportedly been treated for asthma and GI tumors. She was unsure of familial history of other conditions such as hypertension, high cholesterol, stroke, etc.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Ms. A completed high school degree. She reported that she primarily obtained B's and C's in school. She received some tutoring for algebra in middle school, but denied ever having been held back a grade failing any classes or having any problems with attention or hyperactivity. She currently works for the Social Security Administration in data processing. As mentioned, she has returned to full-time work, but continues to perform only light duties due to her physical condition. She is now living on her own. She has never driven. She reported that she continues to perform ADLs independently such as cooking and cleaning. She lost her husband in 2005 and has three adult daughters. She previously reported some concerns that her children wanted her to move into assisted living, but she did not discuss that during this current evaluation. She also reported number of other family members who had recently passed away. She has returned to activities she enjoys such as choir, knitting, and cooking and plans to go on a cruise to the Bahamas at the end of October.

PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY: Ms. A did not report a history of psychological or psychiatric treatment. She reported that her current mood was good, but did describe some anxiety and nervousness about various issues such as her return to work, her upcoming trip, and other events. She reported that this only "comes and goes."

TASKS ADMINISTERED: Clinical Interview, Adult History Questionnaire, Wechsler Test of Adult Reading (WTAR), Mini Mental Status Exam (MMSE), Cognistat Neurobehavioral Cognitive Status Examination, Repeatable Battery for the Assessment of Neuropsychological Status (RBANS; Form XX), Mattis Dementia Rating Scale, 2nd Edition (DRS-2), Neuropsychological Assessment Battery (NAB), Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale, Third Edition (WAIS-III), Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale, Fourth Edition (WAIS-IV), Wechsler Abbreviated Scale of Intelligence (WASI), Test of Variables of Attention (TOVA), Auditory Consonant Trigrams (ACT), Paced Auditory Serial Addition Test (PASAT), Ruff 2 & 7 Selective Attention Test, Symbol Digit Modalities Test (SDMT), Multilingual Aphasia Examination, Second Edition (MAE-II), Token Test, Sentence Repetition, Visual Naming, Controlled Oral Word Association, Spelling Test, Aural Comprehension, Reading Comprehension, Boston Naming Test, Second Edition (BNT-2), Animal Naming Test

Synthetic:
REASON FOR REFERRAL: Ms. A, a 60-year-old African-American woman with a high school education, was referred by Dr. X for a comprehensive neuropsychological evaluation after demonstrating mild cognitive deficits during a follow-up appointment for her stroke in July. The evaluation aims to assess her current cognitive status and guide diagnostic and treatment planning. 

RELEVANT BACKGROUND INFORMATION: Historical data were gathered from medical records and an interview with Ms. A. Key details are summarized here, with a full history available in her medical chart.

HISTORY OF PRESENTING PROBLEM: On 07/26/2009, Ms. A came to the ABC Hospital's emergency department with numbness and weakness in her left hand, slurred speech, and a left facial droop upon waking. Dr. X's neurological evaluation confirmed left hemiparesis. A brain CT showed no intracranial hemorrhage or mass effect, and she received TPA, which led to moderate improvement in her left-sided weakness. The symptoms were attributed to a right middle cerebral artery stroke, and she was moved to the ICU for monitoring. Carotid ultrasound revealed 20% to 30% stenosis in the right ICA and 0% to 19% in the left ICA. She was admitted for inpatient rehabilitation on 07/29/2009 to address residual deficits from her acute ischemic right MCA/CVA. Upon discharge on 08/06/2009, she was mainly under supervision for ADLs and used a rolling walker, gradually transitioning to a cane for ambulation. Home discharge instructions included outpatient physical therapy. She returned to the Sinai ER in August 2009 due to left arm pain, numbness, and weakness lasting 10 to 15 minutes, resembling her stroke. An 08/2009/2009 CT showed "mild chronic microvascular ischemic change of deep white matter," with no acute changes since her last scan. Dr. Y's neurological exam was normal, but she was admitted for further evaluation. An ultrasound of her left upper extremity ruled out deep vein thrombosis. A follow-up CT on 08/10/2009 showed no significant change. An MRI was not possible due to her weight. Discharged on 08/11/2009 in stable condition, this event was deemed non-neurological, although Ms. A considered it a second stroke. At a follow-up with Dr. X on 09/22/2009, a brief neuropsychological screening revealed significant impairments in confrontation naming, abstract verbal reasoning, and memory. A comprehensive evaluation was advised as she planned to resume full-time work. Ms. A reported mild memory issues like trouble remembering conversations and events, and occasional forgetfulness with medication. She also noted slight difficulty with word-finding, problem-solving, and learning new tasks, but denied significant deficits in other cognitive areas. She remains on light duty due to residual left leg weakness and reports no feedback about decreased job performance, though she processes fewer files. She struggles to describe her job and reports falling asleep at work, while still working full-time.

OTHER MEDICAL HISTORY: Ms. A continues to have minor left leg weakness and uses a rolling walker, although motor function has improved. Diagnosed with sleep apnea two years ago, she was counseled by Dr. X to use her CPAP, which she now uses "every other night." Despite initially denying daytime fatigue, she admitted to falling asleep at work, attributing it to computer screen exposure. She reports snoring and disorientation, with a supervisor offering her coffee at times. She sleeps two to five hours per night. Untreated risk factors include obesity and hypercholesterolemia. Her medical history also includes hypertension, asthma, abdominal adenocarcinoma post-hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, colonic polyps post-resection, benign breast lesions post-lumpectomy, and left lower extremity DVT post-anticoagulation (discontinued before her stroke).

CURRENT MEDICATIONS: Aspirin 81 mg daily, Colace 100 mg b.i.d., Lipitor 80 mg daily, and albuterol MDI p.r.n.

SUBSTANCE USE: Ms. A denied alcohol or illicit drug use. She quit smoking one pack per day five to six years ago.

FAMILY MEDICAL HISTORY: Ms. A struggled to provide family medical history. Her mother died of lung cancer three to four years ago. Her father has gout and blood clots. Siblings have been treated for asthma and GI tumors. She is unsure about family history of hypertension, high cholesterol, stroke, etc.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Ms. A completed high school, mainly earning B's and C's. She received algebra tutoring in middle school but was never held back or struggled with attention or hyperactivity. Employed by the Social Security Administration in data processing, she has returned to full-time work on light duties. She lives independently, has never driven, and manages her ADLs like cooking and cleaning. Widowed in 2005, she has three adult daughters. Previously concerned about her children wanting her in assisted living, she didn't mention it this time. She has resumed activities like choir, knitting, and cooking, and plans a Bahamas cruise at the end of October.

PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY: Ms. A reported no psychological or psychiatric treatment history. Although her mood is good, she described occasional anxiety and nervousness about work, her upcoming trip, and other events, noting it "comes and goes."

Synthetic:
REASON FOR REFERRAL: Ms. A, a 60-year-old African-American female with 12 years of education, was referred for a neuropsychological evaluation by Dr. X after she displayed mild cognitive deficits on a neuropsychological screening evaluation during a follow-up appointment for stroke in July. A comprehensive assessment was requested to evaluate current cognitive functioning and aid in diagnostic decisions and treatment planning.

RELEVANT BACKGROUND INFORMATION: Historical information was gathered from a review of available medical records and a clinical interview with Ms. A. A summary of pertinent data is presented below. Please refer to the patient's medical chart for a more complete history.

HISTORY OF PRESENTING PROBLEM: Ms. A arrived at the ABC Hospital emergency department on 07/26/2009, reporting that after waking up that morning, she experienced numbness and weakness in her left hand, slurred speech, and left facial droop. Neurological evaluation with Dr. X confirmed left hemiparesis. Brain CT revealed no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage or mass effect, and she received TPA, showing moderate improvement in left-sided weakness. These symptoms were attributed to a right middle cerebral artery stroke. She was transferred to the ICU for monitoring. An ultrasound of the carotids showed 20% to 30% stenosis of the right ICA and 0% to 19% stenosis of the left ICA. On 07/29/2009, she was admitted for acute inpatient rehabilitation for the treatment of residual functional deficits of her acute ischemic right MCA/CVA. At discharge on 08/06/2009, she was mainly on supervision for all ADLs and walking with a rolling walker but tolerated increased ambulation with a cane. She was discharged home with recommendations for outpatient physical therapy. She returned to the Sinai ER on 08/2009/2009 due to reported left arm pain, numbness, and weakness, lasting 10 to 15 minutes, and she reported it felt "just like the stroke." A Brain CT on 08/2009/2009 was read as showing "mild chronic microvascular ischemic change of deep white matter," but no acute or significant interval change compared to her previous scan. Neurological examination with Dr. Y was within normal limits, but she was admitted for a more extensive workup. Due to left arm pain, an ultrasound was completed on her left upper extremity, revealing a third kidney in her left arm. Follow-up CT on 08/10/2009 showed no significant interval change. MRI could not be completed due to the patient's weight. She was discharged on 08/11/2009 in stable condition after it was determined that this event was not neurological in origin; however, note that Ms. A referred to this as a second stroke. Ms. A presented for a follow-up outpatient neurological evaluation with Dr. X on 09/22/2009, at which time a brief neuropsychological screening was also conducted. She demonstrated significant impairments in confrontation naming, abstract verbal reasoning, and visual and verbal memory, and thus a more comprehensive evaluation was suggested due to her intent to return to her full-time work duty. During the current interview, Ms. A reported noticing mild memory problems, including some difficulty remembering conversations, events, and at times forgetting to take her medications. She also reported mild difficulty finding words in conversation, solving novel problems and tasks (e.g., difficulty learning to use her camcorder), but overall denied significant cognitive deficits in attention, concentration, language, or other areas of cognitive functioning. When asked about her return to work, she said she was still on light duty due to limited physical activity because of residual left leg weakness. She reported that no one had indicated to her that she appeared less capable of performing her job duties, but said that she was also receiving fewer files to process and enter data into the computer at the Social Security Agency where she works. Note also that she had some difficulty explaining exactly what her job involved. She also reported having problems falling asleep at work and that she is working full-time, although on light duty.

OTHER MEDICAL HISTORY: As mentioned, Ms. A continues to have some residual left leg weakness and continues to use a rolling walker for ambulation, but she reported that her motor functioning had improved significantly. She was diagnosed with sleep apnea approximately two years ago and was recently counseled by Dr. X on the need to use her CPAP because she indicated she never used it at night. She reported that since her appointment with Dr. X, she has been using it "every other night." When asked about daytime fatigue, Ms. A initially denied having any difficulties but repeatedly indicated that she was falling asleep at work and thought it was due to looking at a computer screen. She reported at times "snoring" and forgetting where she is and said that a supervisor offered to give her coffee at one point. She receives approximately two to five hours of sleep per night. Other current untreated risk factors include obesity and hypercholesterolemia. Her medical history is also significant for hypertension, asthma, abdominal adenocarcinoma status post hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, colonic benign polyps status post resection, benign lesions of the breast status post lumpectomy, and deep vein thrombosis in the left lower extremity status post six months of anticoagulation (which she had discontinued just prior to her stroke).

CURRENT MEDICATIONS: Aspirin 81 mg daily, Colace 100 mg b.i.d., Lipitor 80 mg daily, and albuterol MDI p.r.n.

SUBSTANCE USE: Ms. A denied drinking alcohol or using illicit drugs. She used to smoke a pack of cigarettes per day, but quit five to six years ago.

FAMILY MEDICAL HISTORY: Ms. A had difficulty providing information on familial medical history. She reported that her mother died three to four years ago from lung cancer. Her father has gout and blood clots. Siblings have reportedly been treated for asthma and GI tumors. She was unsure of familial history of other conditions such as hypertension, high cholesterol, stroke, etc.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Ms. A completed a high school degree. She reported that she primarily obtained B's and C's in school. She received some tutoring for algebra in middle school, but denied ever having been held back a grade, failing any classes, or having any problems with attention or hyperactivity. She currently works for the Social Security Administration in data processing. As mentioned, she has returned to full-time work but continues to perform only light duties due to her physical condition. She is now living on her own. She has never driven. She reported that she continues to perform ADLs independently, such as cooking and cleaning. She lost her husband in 2005 and has three adult daughters. She previously reported some concerns that her children wanted her to move into assisted living, but she did not discuss that during this current evaluation. She also reported a number of other family members who had recently passed away. She has returned to activities she enjoys, such as choir, knitting, and cooking, and plans to go on a cruise to the Bahamas at the end of October.

PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY: Ms. A did not report a history of psychological or psychiatric treatment. She reported that her current mood was good but did describe some anxiety and nervousness about various issues such as her return to work, her upcoming trip, and other events. She reported that this only "comes and goes."

TASKS ADMINISTERED: Clinical Interview, Adult History Questionnaire, Wechsler Test of Adult Reading (WTAR), Mini Mental Status Exam (MMSE), Cognistat Neurobehavioral Cognitive Status Examination, Repeatable Battery for the Assessment of Neuropsychological Status (RBANS; Form XX), Mattis Dementia Rating Scale, 2nd Edition (DRS-2), Neuropsychological Assessment Battery (NAB), Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale, Third Edition (WAIS-III), Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale, Fourth Edition (WAIS-IV), Wechsler Abbreviated Scale of Intelligence (WASI), Test of Variables of Attention (TOVA), Auditory Consonant Trigrams (ACT), Paced Auditory Serial Addition Test (PASAT), Ruff 2 & 7 Selective Attention Test, Symbol Digit Modalities Test (SDMT), Multilingual Aphasia Examination, Second Edition (MAE-II), Token Test, Sentence Repetition, Visual Naming, Controlled Oral Word Association, Spelling Test, Aural Comprehension, Reading Comprehension, Boston Naming Test, Second Edition (BNT-2), Animal Naming Test.

Synthetic:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: This is a 3-year-old female patient who was admitted today due to a history of gagging. She had been doing well until approximately 2 days ago, when the gagging started. She has not experienced any vomiting or fever. The patient has a history of constipation and typically passes stool every two days after receiving an enema. There is no presence of rectal bleeding. She was brought to the hospital with some loose stool and was found to be dehydrated. She received an IV fluid bolus, but subsequently began bleeding from the G-tube site, with fresh blood noted. She was transferred to the PICU. She is hypertensive. Intensivist Dr. X requested an evaluation and an upper endoscopy to identify the bleeding source. The patient tolerated the transfer to PICU well. 

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: PEHO syndrome, infantile spasm, right above-knee amputation, developmental delay, G-tube fundoplication.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: G-tube fundoplication on 05/25/2007. Right above-knee amputation.

ALLERGIES: None.

DIET: She is currently NPO, but at home, she receives PediaSure 4 ounces three times a day through the G-tube, along with 12 ounces of water daily.

MEDICATIONS: Albuterol, Pulmicort, MiraLax 17 g once a week, carnitine, phenobarbital, Depakene, and Reglan.

FAMILY HISTORY: Positive for cancer.

PAST LABORATORY EVALUATION: On 12/27/2007, WBC was 9.3, hemoglobin 7.6, hematocrit 22.1, platelets 132,000. KUB showed large stool with dilated small and large bowel loops. Sodium 140, potassium 4.4, chloride 89, CO2 21, BUN 61, creatinine 2, AST 92 increased, ALT 62 increased, albumin 5.3, total bilirubin 0.1. Earlier today, hemoglobin was 14.5, hematocrit 41.3, platelets 491,000. PT 58 increased, INR 6.6 increased, PTT 75.9 increased.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: VITAL SIGNS: Temperature 99 degrees Fahrenheit, pulse 142 per minute, respirations 34 per minute, weight 8.6 kg. GENERAL: The patient is intubated. HEENT: Atraumatic. Intubated. LUNGS: Good air entry bilaterally, no rales or wheezing. ABDOMEN: Distended with decreased bowel sounds. GENITALIA: Grossly normal female. CNS: The patient is sedated.

IMPRESSION: A 3-year-old female patient with a history of blood passage through the G-tube site and coagulopathy. She has a history of G-tube fundoplication, developmental delay, and PEHO syndrome, which includes progressive encephalopathy and optic atrophy.

PLAN: The plan includes administering vitamin K, FFP, and blood transfusion. An upper endoscopy is being considered. The procedure and informed consent were discussed with the family. The patient tolerated the discussion process well.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: This is a 3-year-old female patient who was admitted today with a history of gagging. She was doing well until about 2 days ago when she developed gagging. No vomiting. No fever. She has a history of constipation and normally passes stool every two days after an enema. No rectal bleeding. She was brought to the hospital with some loose stool. She was found to be dehydrated and was given an IV fluid bolus, but then she started bleeding from the G-tube site. There was some fresh blood coming out of the G-tube site. She was transferred to PICU. She is hypertensive. Intensivist Dr. X requested me to come and look at her and do an upper endoscopy to find the site of bleeding.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: PEHO syndrome, infantile spasm, right above knee amputation, developmental delay, G-tube fundoplication. Additionally, she has a history of having three kidneys.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: G-tube fundoplication on 05/25/2007. Right above knee amputation.

ALLERGIES: None.

DIET: She is NPO now, but at home, she is on PediaSure 4 ounces 3 times a day through G-tube, 12 ounces of water per day.

MEDICATIONS: Albuterol, Pulmicort, MiraLax 17 g once a week, carnitine, phenobarbital, Depakene, and Reglan.

FAMILY HISTORY: Positive for cancer.

PAST LABORATORY EVALUATION: On 12/27/2007; WBC 9.3, hemoglobin 7.6, hematocrit 22.1, platelet 132,000. KUB showed large stool with dilated small and large bowel loops. Sodium 140, potassium 4.4, chloride 89, CO2 21, BUN 61, creatinine 2, AST 92 increased, ALT 62 increased, albumin 5.3, total bilirubin 0.1. Earlier this morning, she had hemoglobin of 14.5, hematocrit 41.3, platelets 491,000. PT 58 increased, INR 6.6 increased, PTT 75.9 increased.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:

VITAL SIGNS: Temperature 99 degrees Fahrenheit, pulse 142 per minute, respirations 34 per minute, weight 8.6 kg.

GENERAL: She is intubated.

HEENT: Atraumatic. She is intubated.

LUNGS: Good air entry bilaterally. No rales or wheezing.

ABDOMEN: Distended. Decreased bowel sounds.

GENITALIA: Grossly normal female.

CNS: She is sedated.

IMPRESSION: A 3-year-old female patient with a history of passage of blood through G-tube site with coagulopathy. She has a history of G-tube fundoplication, developmental delay, and PEHO syndrome, which is progressive encephalopathy optic atrophy.

PLAN: Plan is to give vitamin K, FFP, blood transfusion. Consider upper endoscopy. Procedure and informed consent discussed with the family.

Original: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:,  Left adnexal mass.,POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:,  Left ovarian lesion.,PROCEDURE PERFORMED:  ,Laparoscopy with left salpingo-oophorectomy.,ANESTHESIA:,  General.,ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: , Less than 50 cc.,COMPLICATIONS:,  None.,FINDINGS:,  The labia and perineum were within normal limits.  The hymen was found to be intact.  Laparoscopic findings revealed a 4 cm left adnexal mass, which appeared fluid filled.  There were a few calcifications on the surface of the mass.  The right ovary and fallopian tube appeared normal.  There was no evidence of endometriosis.  The uterus appeared normal in size.  There were no pelvic adhesions noted.,INDICATIONS: , The patient is a 55-year-old gravida 0, para 0 Caucasian female who presents with a left adnexal mass on ultrasound which is 5.3 cm.  She does complain of minimal discomfort.  Bimanual exam was not able to be performed secondary to the vaginal stenosis and completely intact hymen.,PROCEDURE IN DETAIL: , After informed consent was obtained, the patient was taken back to the Operative Suite, prepped and draped, and placed in the dorsal lithotomy position.  A 1 cm skin incision was made in the infraumbilical vault.  While tenting up the abdominal wall, the Veress needle was inserted without difficulty and the abdomen was insufflated.  This was done using appropriate flow and volume of CO2.  The #11 step trocar was then placed without difficulty.  The above findings were confirmed.  A #12 mm port was then placed approximately 2 cm above the pubic symphysis under direct visualization.  Two additional ports were placed, one on the left lateral aspect of the abdominal wall and one on the right lateral aspect of the abdominal wall.  Both #12 step ports were done under direct visualization.  Using a grasper, the mass was tented up at the inferior pelvic ligament and the LigaSure was placed across this and several bites were taken with good visualization while ligating.  The left ovary was then placed in an Endocatch bag and removed through the suprapubic incision.  The skin was extended around this incision and the fascia was extended using the Mayo scissors.  The specimen was removed intact in the Endocatch bag through this site.  Prior to desufflation of the abdomen, the site where the left adnexa was removed was visualized to be hemostatic.  All the port sites were hemostatic as well.  The fascia of the suprapubic incision was then repaired using a running #0 Vicryl stitch on a UR6 needle.  The skin was then closed with #4-0 undyed Vicryl in a subcuticular fashion.  The remaining incisions were also closed with #4-0 undyed Vicryl in a running fashion after all instruments were removed and the abdomen was completely desufflated.  Steri-Strips were placed on each of the incisions.  The patient tolerated the procedure well.  Sponge, lap, and needle count were x2.  She will go home on Vicodin for pain and followup postoperatively in the office where we will review path report with her.
Synthetic: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: A mass in the left adnexa. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: A lesion on the left ovary. PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Laparoscopic left salpingo-oophorectomy. ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia was administered. ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Less than 50 milliliters. COMPLICATIONS: None encountered. FINDINGS: Examination of the labia and perineum revealed no abnormalities. The hymen remained intact. Laparoscopic examination showed a 4 cm mass on the left adnexa, containing fluid. A few calcifications were present on the surface of the mass. The right ovary and fallopian tube appeared normal. There was no sign of endometriosis, and the uterus was normal in size. No pelvic adhesions were observed. INDICATIONS: The patient, a 55-year-old Caucasian female, gravida 0, para 0, presented with a 5.3 cm left adnexal mass noted on ultrasound, and reported minor discomfort. A bimanual examination could not be performed due to vaginal stenosis and an intact hymen. PROCEDURE IN DETAIL: After obtaining informed consent, the patient was transferred to the operating suite, prepared, draped, and positioned in the dorsal lithotomy position. A 1 cm incision was made in the infraumbilical area. With the abdominal wall elevated, a Veress needle was introduced without difficulty, and the abdominal cavity was insufflated with CO2 at appropriate flow and volume. A #11 step trocar was inserted without issues. The findings mentioned above were verified. A 12 mm port was inserted approximately 2 cm above the pubic symphysis under direct vision. Two additional 12 mm ports were introduced on the left and right lateral sides of the abdominal wall, both under direct vision. Using a grasper, the mass was elevated at the inferior pelvic ligament, and the LigaSure was applied across it, with several successful ligations performed under good visualization. The left ovary was placed in an Endocatch bag and extracted through the suprapubic incision. The skin and fascia were extended using Mayo scissors, and the specimen was intactly removed in the Endocatch bag through this site. Before deflating the abdomen, the removal site of the left adnexa was confirmed to be hemostatic. All port sites were also hemostatic. The fascia of the suprapubic incision was repaired with a running #0 Vicryl suture on a UR6 needle, and the skin was closed with #4-0 undyed Vicryl in a subcuticular manner. The other incisions were closed with #4-0 undyed Vicryl in a running fashion after removing all instruments and complete desufflation of the abdomen. Steri-Strips were applied to each incision. The patient tolerated the procedure well. Sponge, lap, and needle counts were correct x2. Postoperatively, she will be discharged with Vicodin for pain management and will have a follow-up visit in the office to discuss the pathology report.

The skin was then closed with #4-0 undyed Vicryl in a subcuticular fashion.  The remaining incisions were also closed with #4-0 undyed Vicryl in a running fashion after all instruments were removed and the abdomen was completely desufflated.  Steri-Strips were placed on each of the incisions.  The patient tolerated the procedure well.  Sponge, lap, and needle count were x2.  She will go home on Vicodin for pain and followup postoperatively in the office where we will review path report with her.

Original: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:,  Nonpalpable right undescended testis.,POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: , Nonpalpable right undescended testis with atrophic right testis.,PROCEDURES: , Examination under anesthesia, diagnostic laparoscopy, right orchiectomy, and left testis fixation.,ANESTHESIA:  ,General inhalation anesthetic with caudal block.,FLUID RECEIVED:  ,250 mL of crystalloids.,ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: , Less than 5 mL.,SPECIMEN:,  The tissue sent to Pathology was right testicular remnant.,ABNORMAL FINDINGS:,  Closed ring on right with atrophic vessels going into the ring and there was obstruction at the shoulder of the ring.  Left had open appearing ring but the scrotum was not filled and vas and vessels going into the ring.,INDICATIONS FOR OPERATION: , The patient is a 2-year-old boy with a right nonpalpable undescended testis.  The plan is for evaluation and repair.,DESCRIPTION OF OPERATION:  ,The patient was taken to the operating room, where surgical consent, operative site, and patient identification were verified.  Once he was anesthetized, a caudal block was placed.  The patient was placed in supine position and examined.  The left testis well within scrotum.  The right was again not palpable despite the patient being asleep with multiple attempts to check.,The patient was then sterilely prepped and draped.  An 8-French feeding tube was then placed within his bladder through the urethra and attached to the drainage.  We then incised the infraumbilical area once he was sterilely prepped and draped, with 15 blade knife, then using Hasson technique with stay stitches in the anterior and posterior rectus fascia sheath of 3-0 Monocryl.  We entered the peritoneum with the 5-mm one-step system.  We then used the short 0-degree lens for laparoscopy.  We then insufflated with carbon dioxide insufflation to pressure of 12 mmHg.  There was no bleeding noted upon evaluation of the abdomen and again the findings were as mentioned with closed ring with vas and vessels going to the left and vessels and absent vas on the right where the closed ring was found.  Because there was no testis found in the abdomen, we then evacuated the gas and closed the fascial sheath with the 3-0 Monocryl tacking sutures.  Then skin was closed with subcutaneous closure of 4-0 Rapide.  A curvilinear upper scrotal incision was made on the right with 15 blade knife and carried down through the subcutaneous tissue with electrocautery.  Electrocautery was used for hemostasis.  A curved tenotomy scissor was used to open the sac.  The tunica vaginalis was visualized and grasped and then dissected up towards external ring.  There was no apparent testicular tissue.  We did remove it, however, tying off the cord structure with a 4-0 Vicryl suture and putting a tagging suture at the base of the tissue sent.  We then closed the subdartos area with the subcutaneous closure of 4-0 chromic.  We then did a similar curvilinear incision on the left side for testicular fixation.  Delivered the testis into the field, which had a type III epididymal attachment and was indeed about 3 to 4 mL in size, which was larger than expected for the patient's age.  We then closed the upper aspect of the subdartos pouch with the 4-0 chromic pursestring suture and placed testis back into the scrotum in the proper orientation and closed the dartos, skin, and subcutaneous closure with 4-0 chromic on left hemiscrotum.  At the end of the procedure, the patient received IV Toradol and had Dermabond tissue adhesive placed on both incisions and left testis was well descended in the scrotum at the end of the procedure.  The patient tolerated procedure well, and was in stable condition upon transfer to the recovery room.
Synthetic:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Right undescended testis that is nonpalpable.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Nonpalpable right undescended testis with atrophy of the right testis.

PROCEDURES: Examination while under anesthesia, diagnostic laparoscopy, orchiectomy on the right side, and fixation of the left testis.

ANESTHESIA: General inhalation anesthesia combined with a caudal block.

FLUID RECEIVED: 250 mL of crystalloid solution.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Less than 5 mL.

SPECIMEN: The specimen sent to Pathology consisted of remnants of the right testis.

ABNORMAL FINDINGS: The right side had a closed ring with atrophied vessels leading into it and an obstruction at the shoulder. The left side displayed an open-appearing ring, but the scrotum was not filled, with vas deferens and vessels entering the ring.

INDICATIONS FOR OPERATION: The patient is a 2-year-old male presenting with a nonpalpable undescended testis on the right side, necessitating evaluation and correction.

DESCRIPTION OF OPERATION: The patient was brought to the operating suite, where verification of surgical consent, operative site, and patient identity was completed. After anesthesia induction and placement of a caudal block, the patient was positioned supine for examination. The left testis was confirmed to be within the scrotum, whereas the right remained nonpalpable despite repeated attempts while the patient was asleep.

The patient was then prepared and draped in a sterile fashion. An 8-French feeding tube was inserted through the urethra into the bladder for drainage. An infraumbilical incision was made using a 15 blade, followed by the Hasson technique with stay sutures of 3-0 Monocryl in the anterior and posterior rectus fascia. Peritoneal entry was achieved with a 5-mm one-step system, and a short 0-degree lens was utilized for laparoscopy. Insufflation with carbon dioxide was performed to a pressure of 12 mmHg. Abdominal evaluation revealed no bleeding and confirmed the previously noted findings: a closed ring on the right with absent vas and vessels, and a left-sided closed ring with vas and vessels.

Due to the absence of a testis in the abdomen, the gas was evacuated, and the fascial layer closed with 3-0 Monocryl tacking sutures. The skin was closed using 4-0 Rapide in a subcutaneous manner. A right upper scrotal curvilinear incision was made with a 15 blade and extended through subcutaneous tissue using electrocautery for hemostasis. A curved tenotomy scissor was used to open the sac, exposing the tunica vaginalis, which was dissected up towards the external ring. No obvious testicular tissue was present; however, we tied off the cord structure with a 4-0 Vicryl suture and tagged the base of the tissue sent. The subdartos area was closed with 4-0 chromic in a subcutaneous manner. A similar incision was made on the left for testicular fixation. The testis was delivered, showing a type III epididymal attachment, measuring 3 to 4 mL, larger than anticipated for the patient's age. The upper subdartos pouch was closed with a 4-0 chromic purse-string suture, and the testis was properly oriented back into the scrotum. The dartos, skin, and subcutaneous layers of the left hemiscrotum were closed with 4-0 chromic. At the procedure's conclusion, IV Toradol was administered, and Dermabond tissue adhesive applied to both incisions. The left testis was well descended within the scrotum post-procedure. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was stable upon transfer to the recovery room.

We entered the peritoneum with the 5-mm one-step system.  We then used the short 0-degree lens for laparoscopy.  We then insufflated with carbon dioxide insufflation to pressure of 12 mmHg.  There was no bleeding noted upon evaluation of the abdomen and again the findings were as mentioned with closed ring with vas and vessels going to the left and vessels and absent vas on the right where the closed ring was found.  Because there was no testis found in the abdomen, we then evacuated the gas and closed the fascial sheath with the 3-0 Monocryl tacking sutures.  Then skin was closed with subcutaneous closure of 4-0 Rapide.  A curvilinear upper scrotal incision was made on the right with 15 blade knife and carried down through the subcutaneous tissue with electrocautery.  Electrocautery was used for hemostasis.  A curved tenotomy scissor was used to open the sac.  The tunica vaginalis was visualized and grasped and then dissected up towards external ring.  There was no apparent testicular tissue.  We did remove it, however, tying off the cord structure with a 4-0 Vicryl suture and putting a tagging suture at the base of the tissue sent.  We then closed the subdartos area with the subcutaneous closure of 4-0 chromic.  We then did a similar curvilinear incision on the left side for testicular fixation.  Delivered the testis into the field, which had a type III epididymal attachment and was indeed about 3 to 4 mL in size, which was larger than expected for the patient's age.  We then closed the upper aspect of the subdartos pouch with the 4-0 chromic pursestring suture and placed testis back into the scrotum in the proper orientation and closed the dartos, skin, and subcutaneous closure with 4-0 chromic on left hemiscrotum.  At the end of the procedure, the patient received IV Toradol and had Dermabond tissue adhesive placed on both incisions and left testis was well descended in the scrotum at the end of the procedure.  The patient tolerated procedure well, and was in stable condition upon transfer to the recovery room.
Synthetic:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Nonpalpable right undescended testis.  
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Nonpalpable right undescended testis with atrophic right testis.  
PROCEDURES: Examination under anesthesia, diagnostic laparoscopy, right orchiectomy, and left testis fixation.  
ANESTHESIA: General inhalation anesthetic with caudal block.  
FLUID RECEIVED: 250 mL of crystalloids.  
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Less than 5 mL.  
SPECIMEN: The tissue sent to Pathology was right testicular remnant.  
ABNORMAL FINDINGS: Closed ring on right with atrophic vessels going into the ring, and there was obstruction at the shoulder of the ring. The left side had an open-appearing ring, though the scrotum was not filled, and vas and vessels were going into the ring.  
INDICATIONS FOR OPERATION: The patient is a 2-year-old boy with a right nonpalpable undescended testis. The plan is for evaluation and repair.

The patient was taken to the operating room, where surgical consent, operative site, and patient identification were verified. He was then anesthetized, and a caudal block was placed. The patient, positioned supine, underwent examination. The left testis was well within the scrotum. Despite the patient being asleep, the right remained nonpalpable after several attempts to locate it. After sterile preparation and draping, an 8-French feeding tube was inserted into the bladder via the urethra for drainage. An infraumbilical incision was made using a 15 blade knife, employing the Hasson technique with stay stitches in the anterior and posterior rectus fascia sheath of 3-0 Monocryl. The peritoneum was accessed with the 5-mm one-step system, and a short 0-degree lens was used for laparoscopy. Carbon dioxide was used for insufflation to a pressure of 12 mmHg. Evaluation revealed no bleeding, and findings were consistent with a closed ring, with vas and vessels on the left and vessels and absent vas on the right. No testis was found in the abdomen, so the gas was evacuated, and the fascial sheath was closed with 3-0 Monocryl tacking sutures. Skin was closed using a subcutaneous closure of 4-0 Rapide. A curvilinear upper scrotal incision was made on the right with a 15 blade knife, dissecting through subcutaneous tissue with electrocautery for hemostasis. A curved tenotomy scissor opened the sac. The tunica vaginalis was visualized, grasped, and dissected towards the external ring. No apparent testicular tissue was found, but a remnant was removed by tying off the cord structure with a 4-0 Vicryl suture, tagging the base of the tissue sent. The subdartos area was closed with subcutaneous closure of 4-0 chromic. A similar incision on the left side was made for testicular fixation. The testis, about 3 to 4 mL in size with a type III epididymal attachment, was delivered into the field, larger than expected for the patient's age. The upper aspect of the subdartos pouch was closed with a 4-0 chromic pursestring suture, and the testis was placed back into the scrotum in the correct orientation. The dartos, skin, and subcutaneous layers were closed with 4-0 chromic on the left hemiscrotum. At the procedure's end, the patient received IV Toradol, and Dermabond tissue adhesive was applied to both incisions. The left testis was well descended in the scrotum. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was stable upon transfer to the recovery room.

Original: TITLE OF OPERATION: , Placement of right new ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunts Strata valve and to removal of right frontal Ommaya reservoir.,INDICATION FOR SURGERY: , The patient is a 2-month-old infant, born premature with intraventricular hemorrhage and Ommaya reservoir recommendation for removal and replacement with a new VP shunt.,PREOP DIAGNOSIS: , Hydrocephalus.,POSTOP DIAGNOSIS: , Hydrocephalus.,PROCEDURE DETAIL: , The patient was brought to the operating room, underwent induction of general endotracheal airway, positioned supine, head turned towards left.  The right side prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.  Next, using a 15 blade scalpel, two incisions were made, one in the parietooccipital region and.  The second just lateral to the umbilicus.  Once this was clear, the Bactiseal catheter was then tunneled.  This was connected to a Strata valve.  The Strata valve was programmed to a setting of 1.01 and this was ensured.  The small burr hole was then created.  The area was then coagulated.  Once this was completed, new Bactiseal catheter was then inserted.  It was connected to the Strata valve.  There was good distal flow.  The distal end was then inserted into the peritoneal region via trocar.  Once this was insured, all the wounds were irrigated copiously and closed with 3-0 Vicryl and 4-0 Caprosyn as well as Indermil glue.  The right frontal incision was then opened.  The Ommaya reservoir identified and removed.  The wound was then also closed with an inverted 3-0 Vicryl and 4-0 Caprosyn.  Once all the wounds were completed, dry sterile dressings were applied.  The patient was then transported back to the ICU in stable condition intubated.  Blood loss minimal.  All sponge and needle counts were correct.
Synthetic:
TITLE OF OPERATION: Placement of a new right ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt with Strata valve, and removal of the right frontal Ommaya reservoir.

INDICATION FOR SURGERY: The patient is a 2-month-old infant, born prematurely with an intraventricular hemorrhage, for whom the removal of the Ommaya reservoir and installation of a new VP shunt was recommended.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Hydrocephalus.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Hydrocephalus.

PROCEDURE DETAIL: The patient was taken to the operating room and underwent induction of general anesthesia with an endotracheal tube, placed in a supine position with the head turned to the left. The right side was then prepared and draped in a standard sterile manner. Using a 15 blade scalpel, two incisions were created: one in the parietooccipital region and another just lateral to the umbilicus. After this, the Bactiseal catheter was tunneled and connected to a Strata valve, which was set to a level of 1.01. A small burr hole was made, and the area was coagulated. Subsequently, a new Bactiseal catheter was inserted and attached to the Strata valve, with good distal flow observed. The distal end was advanced into the peritoneal region using a trocar. After confirming proper placement, all wounds were thoroughly irrigated and closed with 3-0 Vicryl and 4-0 Caprosyn sutures, along with Indermil adhesive. The right frontal incision was opened, the Ommaya reservoir was identified and excised, and the wound closed with inverted 3-0 Vicryl and 4-0 Caprosyn sutures. Once all closures were completed, dry sterile dressings were applied. The patient was transported back to the ICU in stable condition, still intubated. Blood loss was minimal, and all sponge and needle counts were accurate.

Original: ADMITTING DIAGNOSES:,1.  Leiomyosarcoma.,2.  History of pulmonary embolism.,3.  History of subdural hematoma.,4.  Pancytopenia.,5.  History of pneumonia.,PROCEDURES DURING HOSPITALIZATION:,1.  Cycle six of CIVI-CAD (Cytoxan, Adriamycin, and DTIC) from 07/22/2008 to 07/29/2008.,2.  CTA, chest PE study showing no evidence for pulmonary embolism.,3.  Head CT showing no evidence of acute intracranial abnormalities.,4.  Sinus CT, normal mini-CT of the paranasal sinuses.,HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  ,Ms. ABC is a pleasant 66-year-old Caucasian female who first palpated a mass in the left posterior arm in spring of 2007.  The mass increased in size and she was seen by her primary care physician and referred to orthopedic surgeon.  MRI showed inflammation and was thought to be secondary to rheumatoid arthritis.  The mass increased in size.  She eventually underwent a partial resection found to have pathologic grade 2 leiomyosarcoma, margins were impossible to assess, but were likely positive.  She was evaluated by Dr. X and Dr. Y and a decision was made to proceed with preoperative chemotherapy.  She began treatment with CIVI-CAD in December 2007.  Her course was complicated by pulmonary embolus, pneumonia, and subdural hematoma while on anticoagulation.  She eventually underwent surgical resection on May 1, 2008 with small area of residual disease, but otherwise clear margins.,HOSPITAL COURSE:,1.  Leiomyosarcoma, the patient was admitted to Hem/Onco B Service under attending Dr. XYZ for cycle six of continuous IV infusion Cytoxan, Adriamycin, and DTIC, which she tolerated well.,2.  History of pulmonary embolism.  Upon admission, the patient reported an approximate two-week history of dyspnea on exertion and some mild chest pain.  She underwent a CTA, which showed no evidence of pulmonary embolism and the patient was started on prophylactic doses of Lovenox at 40 mg a day.  She had no further complaints throughout the hospitalization with any shortness of breath or chest pain.,3.  History of subdural hematoma, also on admission the patient noted some mild intermittent headaches that were fleeting in nature, several a day that would resolve on their own.  Her headaches were not responding to pain medication and so on 07/24/2008, we obtained a head CT that showed no evidence of acute intracranial abnormalities.  The patient also had a history of sinusitis and so a sinus CT scan was obtained, which was normal.,4.  Pancytopenia.  On admission, the patient's white blood count was 3.4, hemoglobin 11.3, platelet count 82, and ANC of 2400.  The patient's counts were followed throughout admission. Synthetic:
ADMITTING DIAGNOSES: 1. Leiomyosarcoma. 2. History of pulmonary embolism. 3. History of subdural hematoma. 4. Pancytopenia. 5. History of pneumonia.

PROCEDURES DURING HOSPITALIZATION: 1. Cycle six of CIVI-CAD (Cytoxan, Adriamycin, and DTIC) from 07/22/2008 to 07/29/2008. 2. CTA, chest PE study showing no evidence for pulmonary embolism. 3. Head CT showing no evidence of acute intracranial abnormalities. 4. Sinus CT, normal mini-CT of the paranasal sinuses.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Ms. ABC, a 66-year-old Caucasian female, initially detected a mass in her left posterior arm during the spring of 2007. The mass enlarged, prompting her to consult her primary care doctor, who then referred her to an orthopedic surgeon. An MRI suggested inflammation, potentially related to rheumatoid arthritis. As the mass continued to grow, she underwent a partial resection, revealing a pathologic grade 2 leiomyosarcoma, with likely positive margins. Evaluated by Dr. X and Dr. Y, she began preoperative chemotherapy with CIVI-CAD in December 2007. Her treatment was complicated by occurrences of pulmonary embolism, pneumonia, and subdural hematoma while on anticoagulation. Surgical resection was performed on May 1, 2008, showing a small area of residual disease but clear margins otherwise.

HOSPITAL COURSE: 1. Leiomyosarcoma: Admitted to the Hem/Onco B Service under Dr. XYZ for cycle six of continuous IV infusion Cytoxan, Adriamycin, and DTIC, which she tolerated well. 2. History of pulmonary embolism: Upon arrival, the patient mentioned a two-week history of exertional dyspnea and mild chest discomfort. A CTA was conducted with no evidence of pulmonary embolism, and prophylactic Lovenox at 40 mg daily was initiated. No further respiratory symptoms were noted during her stay. 3. History of subdural hematoma: The patient reported mild, intermittent headaches, occurring several times daily and resolving spontaneously. These headaches did not respond to pain medication, leading to a head CT on 07/24/2008 which showed no acute intracranial abnormalities. A sinus CT was also normal. 4. Pancytopenia: On admission, her white blood count was 3.4, hemoglobin 11.3, platelet count 82, and ANC 2400. Although her ANC dipped to 900 on 07/26/2008, requiring a neutropenic diet, it rose to 1100 at discharge, allowing her to resume a regular diet. Her discharge white blood cell count was 1.4, hemoglobin 11.2, and platelet count 140. 5. History of pneumonia: No signs of pneumonia were observed during admission.

DISPOSITION: Discharged home in stable condition. DIET: Regular, less neutropenic. ACTIVITY: Resume previous activity level. FOLLOWUP: Scheduled for lab work with Dr. XYZ on 08/05/2008 and a return visit to the cancer center on 08/12/2008 at 10:20 a.m. Advised to monitor for fevers over 100.5 and seek earlier consultation if any issues arise. 

The patient tolerated the procedure well.

Original: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: , Extremely large basal cell carcinoma, right lower lid.,POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:,  Extremely large basal cell carcinoma, right lower lid.,TITLE OF OPERATION: , Excision of large basal cell carcinoma, right lower lid, and repaired with used dorsal conjunctival flap in the upper lid and a large preauricular skin graft.,PROCEDURE: , The patient was brought into the operating room and prepped and draped in usual fashion.  Xylocaine 2% with epinephrine was injected beneath the conjunctiva and skin of the lower lid and also beneath the conjunctiva and skin of the upper lid.  A frontal nerve block was also given on the right upper lid.  The anesthetic agent was also injected in the right preauricular region which would provide a donor graft for the right lower lid defect. Synthetic:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Extremely large basal cell carcinoma, right lower eyelid. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Extremely large basal cell carcinoma, right lower eyelid. TITLE OF OPERATION: Excision of large basal cell carcinoma, right lower eyelid, followed by repair using a dorsal conjunctival flap from the upper eyelid and a substantial preauricular skin graft. PROCEDURE: The patient was taken into the operating room, where standard preparation and draping procedures were followed. Xylocaine 2% with epinephrine was administered under the conjunctiva and skin of both the lower and upper eyelids. Additionally, a frontal nerve block was applied to the right upper eyelid. The anesthetic was also injected in the right preauricular area, which served as the graft donor site for the defect in the right lower eyelid. Margins of 3 to 4 mm were marked with a marker, and a #15 Bard-Parker blade was used to perform an incision at the nasal and temporal edges of the lesion. 

The incision was extended inferiorly, and using Steven scissors, the normal skin, muscle, and conjunctiva were excised downward. The specimen was labeled and sent to pathology for a frozen section analysis. Hemostasis was achieved using wet-field cautery, and the right upper eyelid was turned outward. An incision, 3 mm above the eyelid margin, was made along the entire length of the upper eyelid with the Bard-Parker blade, reaching the orbicularis muscle. Steven scissors were employed to separate the tarsus from the orbicularis. Vertical incisions were made nasally and temporally, creating a large dorsal conjunctival flap with the conjunctiva attached at the superior end. This flap was placed into the defect in the lower eyelid and secured with multiple interrupted 6-0 Vicryl sutures at the nasal, temporal, and inferior edges. 

The skin defect was measured, and an appropriately sized large preauricular graft was taken from the right preauricular area. The donor site was closed with interrupted 5-0 Prolene sutures, and the preauricular graft was sutured into place with multiple interrupted 6-0 silk sutures. The upper edge of the graft was attached to the upper eyelid after making an incision in the gray line with a Superblade, and the top portion of the skin graft was sewn to the upper eyelid through the anterior lamella created by the incision. 

Cryotherapy was applied to the nasal and temporal edges of the excision area due to the presence of positive margins. Afterwards, an antibiotic steroid ointment was applied, and a light pressure dressing was placed. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the recovery room in stable condition.

Synthetic:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Extremely large basal cell carcinoma, right lower lid. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Extremely large basal cell carcinoma, right lower lid. TITLE OF OPERATION: Excision of large basal cell carcinoma, right lower lid, repaired with dorsal conjunctival flap in the upper lid and a large preauricular skin graft. PROCEDURE: The patient was brought into the operating room, prepped, and draped in the usual manner. Xylocaine 2% with epinephrine was administered beneath the conjunctiva and skin of both the lower and upper lids. A frontal nerve block was applied to the right upper lid. Additionally, the anesthetic was injected in the right preauricular area to prepare for the donor graft. The area was marked with margins of 3 to 4 mm using a marking pen, and a #15 Bard-Parker blade was employed to incise the nasal and temporal boundaries of the lesion. 

The incision was extended inferiorly, and normal skin, muscle, and conjunctiva were excised using Steven scissors. The specimen was marked and sent to pathology for frozen section analysis. Hemostasis was achieved with wet-field cautery. The right upper lid was everted, and a 3 mm incision above the lid margin was performed along the full length of the upper lid using a Bard-Parker blade. The incision reached the orbicularis, and Steven scissors separated the tarsus from the underlying orbicularis. Vertical cuts were made nasally and temporally, and a large dorsal conjunctival flap was fashioned, remaining attached superiorly. It was placed into the lower lid defect and secured with multiple interrupted 6-0 Vicryl sutures nasally, temporally, and inferiorly. 

The skin defect was measured, and an appropriate preauricular graft was harvested from the right preauricular area. The donor site was closed with interrupted 5-0 Prolene sutures, while the preauricular graft was attached with multiple interrupted 6-0 silk sutures. The upper graft edge was connected to the upper lid after creating an incision in the gray line using a Superblade, and the graft's superior portion was sutured to the upper lid through the anterior lamella formed by the razor blade incision. 

Cryotherapy was applied to the nasal and temporal margins due to positive excision margins. Following this, an antibiotic steroid ointment was instilled, and a light pressure dressing was applied. The patient tolerated the procedure well, and the operation was completed successfully. The patient was then sent to the recovery room in good condition.
