Original: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:,  Carcinoma of the left breast.,POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:,  Carcinoma of the left breast.,PROCEDURE PERFORMED: , True cut needle biopsy of the breast.,GROSS FINDINGS:  ,This 65-year-old female on exam was noted to have dimpling and puckering of the skin associated with nipple discharge.  On exam, she has a noticeable carcinoma of the left breast with dimpling, puckering, and erosion through the skin.  At this time, a true cut needle biopsy was performed.,PROCEDURE: , The patient was taken to operating room, is laid in the supine position, sterilely prepped and draped in the usual fashion.  The area over the left breast was infiltrated with 1:1 mixture of 0.25% Marcaine and 1% Xylocaine.  Using a #18 gauge automatic true cut needle core biopsy, five biopsies were taken of the left breast in core fashion.  Hemostasis was controlled with pressure.  The patient tolerated the procedure well, pending the results of biopsy.
Synthetic: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Carcinoma of the left breast. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Carcinoma of the left breast. PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Core needle biopsy of the breast. GROSS FINDINGS: This 65-year-old woman presented with skin dimpling and puckering, along with nipple discharge. Examination revealed a prominent carcinoma of the left breast, evidenced by dimpling, puckering, and skin erosion. A core needle biopsy was performed at this stage. PROCEDURE: The patient was brought to the operating room, positioned supine, and prepared and draped in the standard sterile manner. The left breast area was anesthetized using a 1:1 mixture of 0.25% Marcaine and 1% Xylocaine. Five core biopsies of the left breast were obtained using an #18 gauge automatic core needle. Hemostasis was achieved with pressure. The patient tolerated the procedure well, and we await the biopsy results.

At this time, a true cut needle biopsy was performed.,PROCEDURE:, The patient was taken to the operating room, laid in the supine position, sterilely prepped and draped in the usual fashion. The area over the left breast was infiltrated with 1:1 mixture of 0.25% Marcaine and 1% Xylocaine. Using a #18 gauge automatic true cut needle core biopsy, five biopsies were taken of the left breast in core fashion. Hemostasis was controlled with pressure. The patient tolerated the procedure well, pending the results of biopsy.

Synthetic: HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 53-year-old right-handed man who comes to the clinic for further assessment of double vision. He mentions that he was in his usual state of health when he woke up one morning in January 2009 and noticed double vision. He reports that closing either eye made the double vision go away. The double vision completely resolved within an hour, allowing him to drive. However, the following day, he woke up with double vision again. Over the course of the week, the double vision increased in both intensity and frequency, becoming severe by the second week. He recalls contacting Sinai Hospital and speaking with a doctor who advised him to come in for an assessment. He was evaluated by a primary care physician and referred for an ophthalmologic evaluation, which led to a referral to the emergency department for an urgent MRI to check for a possible aneurysm. The patient reports that the MRI was normal, and he was sent home. Over the ensuing month, his double vision improved, yet he still experiences continuous diplopia. While previously he saw two objects far apart on a horizontal plane, they are now much closer together. He has not resumed driving and is not working due to the double vision. There is no temporal fluctuation in his symptoms. Recently, over the past month, he has developed pain above his right eye, which feels like it is beneath his right eyelid. He denies experiencing any swallowing difficulties, speech problems, weakness, numbness, tingling, or other neurological symptoms. A neurology consultation is documented in the computer system. Dr. X examined the patient on February 2, 2009, in the emergency department. An MRI showed a questionable 3 mm aneurysm of the medial left supraclinoid internal carotid artery, with no abnormalities on the right. An MRV was negative, and an MRI of the brain with and without contrast was also negative. An MRI of the orbit with and without contrast was normal. The impression was that the patient should follow up for a potential evaluation for myasthenia gravis or another disorder. During the exam, it was noted that he had right eyelid drooping and left gaze diplopia. The pupils were equal, round, and reactive to light. His neurological exam was otherwise completely normal. According to Dr. X's note, the ophthalmologist who saw him suspected right eye drooping and an abnormal pupil. There were also right medial rectus and potentially other extraocular issues. The official ophthalmologic consultation is not available to me today. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient denies any previous medical history. He currently lacks a primary care physician as he is uninsured. MEDICATIONS: He is not taking any medications. ALLERGIES: He has no known drug allergies. SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient lives with his wife. He was employed as an IT software developer but has been out of work for several months. He smokes fewer than a pack of cigarettes daily. He denies using alcohol or illicit drugs. FAMILY HISTORY: His mother passed away from a stroke in her 90s. His father had colon cancer. He is not aware of any family members with neurological conditions. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: A full review of systems was conducted and was negative except for what has been previously mentioned. This is documented in the handwritten notes from today's visit. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Vital Signs: BP 124/76.

However, the double vision recurred the following day and worsened in intensity and frequency over the next week, becoming severe by the second week. Previously, the two images were widely separated on a horizontal plane; now, they are much closer. He continues to abstain from driving and working due to the double vision. There is no temporal fluctuation. More recently, he has developed right supraorbital pain, feeling as if there is discomfort beneath his right lid. He denies dysphagia, dysarthria, weakness, numbness, tingling, or other neurological symptoms. A neurology consultation exists in the computer system. MRV was negative, and MRI of the brain with and without contrast was also negative. The MRI of the orbit with and without contrast appeared normal. His impression was to consider evaluation for myasthenia gravis or another disorder. At examination, right lid ptosis and left gaze diplopia were documented. Pupils were equal, round, and reactive to light. The rest of his neurological examination was normal. According to Dr. X's notes, the ophthalmologist observed right eye ptosis and an abnormal pupil, along with right medial rectus and possibly other extraocular issues. The official ophthalmologic consultation is unavailable today.

FAMILY HISTORY: His mother died of a stroke in her 90s. His father had colon cancer. He is unaware of any family members with neurological disorders.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: A complete review of systems was obtained and was negative except as mentioned above. This is documented in the handwritten notes from today's visit.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Vital Signs: BP 124/76

Synthetic: HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: This is a 48-year-old African American male with stage IV chronic kidney disease, probably due to HIV nephropathy, who comes to the clinic for follow-up after missing previous appointments. His last visit here was on 05/29/2007 with Dr. X. This is my first time meeting the patient. His renal insufficiency history goes back to 06/2006 when he was admitted for an HIV-related issue. He is uncertain about the specific cause of that hospitalization, but he was diagnosed with renal insufficiency and monitored in our Renal Clinic for about a year. His baseline creatinine was between 3.2 and 3.3 during that time. Initially, he had not adhered to his HAART regimen, but now he is very compliant with HIV treatment and under Dr. Y's care in our Infectious Disease Clinic. He is on a three-drug antiretroviral regimen. The latest CD4 count was 350 in 03/2008. Since his last clinic visit, he has had no complications related to HIV. He also receives care from Dr. Z at the outpatient VA Clinic in ABCD, although he hasn't seen her in a year. An AV fistula was placed in late 2006. Recent lab work from 06/11/2008 shows a serum creatinine of 3.8, corresponding to a GFR of 22, and a potassium level of 5.9. These tests were ordered by his infectious disease physician, prompting their suggestion for further evaluation at our clinic. His only current complaint is difficulty sleeping. Ambien, prescribed by his primary care doctor, hasn't significantly helped. He finds it hard to fall asleep, and even when Ambien helps, he only sleeps for about two hours before waking. He feels fatigued during the day but does not nap. He has no history of excessive snoring, apnea, falling asleep at work, or while driving. He has never undergone a formal sleep study. He works in sales at a local butcher shop. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: He denies any appetite changes and has gained weight recently. He denies nausea, vomiting, or abdominal discomfort. He reports no pruritus or lower extremity edema. All other systems are reviewed and negative. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: 1. Stage IV chronic kidney disease with a most recent GFR of 22. 2. HIV diagnosed in 09/2006 with the most recent CD4 count of 350 in 03/2008. 3. Hyperlipidemia. 4. Hypertension. 5. Secondary hyperparathyroidism. 6. Status post right upper extremity AV fistula in the fall of 2006. 7. History of a right brachial plexus palsy. 8. Recent lower back pain, status post lumbar steroid injection. ALLERGIES: He reports headaches from Vitamin D. MEDICATIONS: 1. Kaletra daily. 2. Epivir once daily. 3. Ziagen twice daily. 4. Lasix 20 mg b.i.d. 5. Valsartan 20 mg b.i.d. 6. Ambien 10 mg q.h.s. SOCIAL HISTORY: He resides in ABCD and works at the sales counter of a local butcher shop. He continues to smoke a pack of cigarettes daily, a habit he has maintained for 28 years. He denies alcohol or illicit drug use. FAMILY HISTORY: His mother is deceased and had some paralysis before she passed. His father died at 64 from head and neck cancer. He has a 56-year-old brother with type 2 diabetes and blindness from diabetic retinopathy, a 41-year-old brother with hypertension, and a sister with thyroid disease. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: VITAL SIGNS: Weight is 191 pounds. Temperature is 97.1. Pulse is 94. Blood pressure by automatic cuff is 173/97 and by manual cuff 180/90. HEENT: Oropharynx is clear without thrush or ulceration. NECK: Supple without lymphadenopathy or thyromegaly. HEART: Regular with normal S1 and S2. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops. No JVD. LUNGS: Clear to auscultation bilaterally without wheezes, rhonchi, or crackles. ABDOMEN: Soft, nontender, nondistended, without abdominal bruit or organomegaly. MUSCULOSKELETAL: Difficulty with abduction of the right shoulder. ACCESS: Right forearm AV fistula with audible bruit and palpable thrill, no stenosis noted. Vascular access appears ready for use. EXTREMITIES: No peripheral edema. SKIN: No bruises, petechiae, or rash. LABS: Sodium 140, potassium 5.9, chloride 114, bicarbonate 18. BUN 49, creatinine 4.3. GFR 19. Albumin 3.2. Protein 7. AST 17, ALT 16, alkaline phosphatase 106. Total bilirubin 0.4. Calcium 9.1, phosphorus 4.7, PTH 448. Corrected calcium 9.7. WBC 8.9, hemoglobin 13.4, platelet 226. Total cholesterol 234, triglycerides 140, LDL 159, HDL 47. Ferritin 258, iron 55, and percent saturation 24. IMPRESSION: This is a 48-year-old African American male with stage IV chronic kidney disease likely due to HIV nephropathy, although no renal biopsy has been performed. He has been noncompliant with the Renal Clinic and is here for follow-up at the suggestion of his Infectious Disease doctors. RECOMMENDATIONS: 1. Renal: His serum creatinine is worsening, previously 3.2 in 05/2007, now 4.3, indicating a GFR of 19. This is stage IV chronic kidney disease. Vascular access seems ready for use, and he might be showing early uremic signs with sleep difficulties. No other uremic signs are present. I'll coordinate with the dialysis educator to enroll him in dialysis classes. He's received information but hasn't enrolled yet. I've advised him to continue exercising his right forearm. I'll also contact the transplant coordinator for a potential transplant evaluation. Given the progression of his kidney disease, dialysis may start soon. 2. Hypertension: I've added labetalol 100 mg b.i.d. to his regimen. No current signs of volume overload, but if this changes, Lasix can be increased. Target blood pressure is under 130/80. 3. Hyperkalemia: I'll instruct him on a low-potassium diet and reduce valsartan to 20 mg daily. We'll recheck potassium in a week. Persistent elevation may necessitate dialysis. 4. Bone metabolism: His PTH is elevated, so I'll add PhosLo 800 mg t.i.d. with meals. His corrected calcium is 9.7, so we'll avoid calcium-containing phosphate binders. 5. Acid-base: His bicarbonate is 18, so I'll start sodium bicarbonate 650 mg three tablets t.i.d. 6. Anemia: His hemoglobin is at the goal for this stage of kidney disease, and his iron stores are adequate.

Synthetic:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: This is a 48-year-old black male with stage IV chronic kidney disease, likely secondary to HIV nephropathy, presenting to the clinic for follow-up after previously missing appointments. He was last seen in this clinic on 05/29/2007 by Dr. X. This is my first encounter with the patient. The history of renal insufficiency dates back to 06/2006 when he was hospitalized for an HIV-associated complication. He is uncertain of the exact cause of the hospitalization then, but renal insufficiency was diagnosed, and he was followed in our Renal Clinic for about a year. His baseline creatinine was between 3.2 to 3.3. Initially, he had been noncompliant with his HAART regimen. Since then, he has adhered to his HIV treatment and is under the care of Dr. Y in our Infectious Disease Clinic. He is on a three-drug antiretroviral regimen. His last CD4 count in 03/2008 was 350. He has experienced no HIV complications since his last clinic visit. The patient also sees Dr. Z at the outpatient VA Clinic in ABCD, though it's been nearly a year since his last visit with her. An AV fistula was placed in late 2006. The latest labs from 06/11/2008 show a serum creatinine of 3.8, indicating a GFR of 22 and a potassium of 5.9. These results were drawn by his infectious disease doctor, prompting their recommendation for clinic re-evaluation. The patient reports difficulty sleeping, for which Ambien was prescribed by his primary care doctor, but it has not significantly improved his sleep issues. He reports trouble falling asleep; Ambien allows for about two hours of sleep before waking. He feels tired during the day but does not take naps. There is no history of excessive snoring or apneic periods. He has not fallen asleep at work or while driving and has never undergone a formal sleep study. He continues to work in sales at a local butcher shop.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: He denies any change in appetite. He has gained some weight recently. He denies nausea, vomiting, or abdominal discomfort. He denies pruritus, but reports mild lower extremity edema. All other systems are reviewed and negative.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: 
1. Stage IV chronic kidney disease with the most recent GFR of 22.
2. HIV diagnosed in 09/2006 with the most recent CD4 count of 350 in 03/2008.
3. Hyperlipidemia.
4. Hypertension.
5. Secondary hyperparathyroidism.
6. Status post right upper extremity AV fistula in the fall of 2006.
7. History of a right brachial plexus palsy.
8. Recent lower back pain, status post lumbar steroid injection.

ALLERGIES: HE SAYS THAT VITAMIN D HAS CAUSED HEADACHES.

MEDICATIONS: 
1. Kaletra daily.
2. Epivir one daily.
3. Ziagen two daily.
4. Lasix 20 mg b.i.d.
5. Valsartan 20 mg b.i.d.
6. Ambien 10 mg q.h.s.

SOCIAL HISTORY: He lives in ABCD and works at the sales counter of a local butcher shop. He still smokes a pack of cigarettes daily, as he has for 28 years. He denies alcohol or illicit substance use.

FAMILY HISTORY: His mother is deceased, reportedly having had some form of paralysis before passing. His father died at age 64 from head and neck cancer. He has a 56-year-old brother with type-two diabetes and blindness due to diabetic retinopathy. Another brother, aged 41, has hypertension. He has a sister with thyroid disease.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: 
VITAL SIGNS: Weight is 191 pounds. Temperature is 97.1. Pulse is 94. Blood pressure by automatic cuff is 173/97, and by manual cuff is 180/90.
HEENT: Oropharynx is clear with no thrush or ulceration.
NECK: Supple without lymphadenopathy or thyromegaly.
HEART: Regular with normal S1 and S2. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops. No JVD.
LUNGS: Clear to auscultation bilaterally without wheezes, rhonchi, or crackles.
ABDOMEN: Soft, nontender, nondistended, without abdominal bruit or organomegaly.
MUSCULOSKELETAL: Difficulty with abduction of the right shoulder.
ACCESS: Right forearm AV fistula with an audible bruit and a palpable thrill. No stenosis signs. Vascular access appears ready to use.
EXTREMITIES: Mild peripheral edema noted.
SKIN: No bruises, petechiae, or rash.

LABS: Sodium 140, potassium 5.9, chloride 114, bicarbonate 18. BUN 49, creatinine 4.3. GFR 19. Albumin 3.2. Protein 7. AST 17, ALT 16, alkaline phosphatase 106. Total bilirubin 0.4. Calcium 9.1, phosphorus 4.7, PTH 448. Corrected calcium 9.7. WBC 8.9, hemoglobin 13.4, platelets 226. Total cholesterol 234, triglycerides 140, LDL 159, HDL 47. Ferritin 258, iron 55, percent saturation 24.

IMPRESSION: This is a 48-year-old black male with stage IV chronic kidney disease likely secondary to HIV nephropathy, though no renal biopsy history is present, who has been noncompliant with the Renal Clinic and presents today for follow-up at the recommendation of his Infectious Disease doctors.

RECOMMENDATIONS: 
1. Renal. Serum creatinine is worsening, previously 3.2 in 05/2007, now 4.3, representing a GFR of 19. This is stage IV chronic kidney disease. Vascular access appears ready for use. Sleep difficulty could be early signs of uremia, though no other uremic symptoms present. I will contact the dialysis educator to enroll the patient in dialysis classes. He received dialysis literature but has not yet started classes. Encouraged him to exercise his right forearm. Contacting the transplant coordinator for a possible evaluation for transplant. Anticipating the need to start dialysis soon.
2. Hypertension. Added labetolol 100 mg b.i.d. to the antihypertensive regimen. No current signs of volume overload, though Lasix could be increased if this develops. Goal blood pressure is less than 130/80.
3. Hyperkalemia. Instructed on a low-potassium diet and decreased valsartan to 20 mg daily. He will return in a week to recheck potassium. If potassium remains elevated, dialysis initiation may be needed.
4. Bone metabolism. PTH is elevated, so PhosLo 800 mg t.i.d. with meals is added. Corrected calcium is 9.7; calcium-containing phosphate binders are avoided.
5. Acid base. Bicarbonate is 18, so sodium bicarbonate 650 mg three tablets t.i.d. is initiated.
6. Anemia. Hemoglobin is at goal for this stage of chronic kidney disease. Iron stores are adequate.

There are no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. I am going to touch base with the dialysis educator and try to get The patient in to the dialysis teaching classes. His iron stores are adequate.

Synthetic: HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: This is a 48-year-old black male with stage IV chronic kidney disease, likely secondary to HIV nephropathy, who comes to the clinic for follow-up after missing earlier appointments. He was last evaluated here on 05/29/2007 by Dr. X. This is my first encounter with the patient. His renal insufficiency history traces back to 06/2006, linked to an HIV-related issue during hospitalization. He is unclear on the exact reason for that hospitalization but was diagnosed with renal insufficiency and was monitored in our Renal Clinic for about a year. His creatinine levels during that period ranged from 3.2 to 3.3. Initially noncompliant with his HAART regimen, he has since adhered well to his HIV treatment and is under the care of Dr. Y in our Infectious Disease Clinic. He is on a three-drug antiretroviral therapy, with his last CD4 count recorded at 350 in 03/2008. He has experienced no HIV complications since his last clinic visit. The patient also sees Dr. Z at the ABCD outpatient VA Clinic, though it has been about a year since his last visit. An AV fistula was placed in late 2006. Recent lab results from 06/11/2008 show a serum creatinine of 3.8, correlating to a GFR of 22, and a potassium level of 5.9. These results were drawn by his infectious disease doctor, recommending further evaluation in our clinic. The patient reports difficulty sleeping, having tried Ambien without significant benefit. He experiences trouble falling asleep, with Ambien providing only about two hours of sleep before awakening. He feels tired during the day but does not nap. He does not snore excessively or have apnea, nor does he fall asleep at work or while driving. He has never had a formal sleep study. He continues working in sales at a local butcher shop. The patient tolerated these examinations well. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: He denies any changes in appetite, has gained weight recently, and denies nausea, vomiting, or abdominal discomfort. He denies pruritus and lower extremity edema. All other systems are reviewed and negative. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: 1. Stage IV chronic kidney disease with a recent GFR of 22. 2. HIV diagnosed in 09/2006 with a recent CD4 count of 350 in 03/2008. 3. Hyperlipidemia. 4. Hypertension. 5. Secondary hyperparathyroidism. 6. Status post right upper extremity AV fistula in fall of 2006. 7. History of a right brachial plexus palsy. 8. Recent lower back pain, status post lumbar steroid injection. ALLERGIES: Reports headaches caused by Vitamin D. MEDICATIONS: 1. Kaletra daily. 2. Epivir one daily. 3. Ziagen two daily. 4. Lasix 20 mg b.i.d. 5. Valsartan 20 mg b.i.d. 6. Ambien 10 mg q.h.s. SOCIAL HISTORY: Resides in ABCD, employed at a local butcher shop sales counter. Continues smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for 28 years. Denies alcohol or illicit substance use. FAMILY HISTORY: His mother, deceased, had some paralysis before passing. His father died at 64 from head and neck cancer. He has a 56-year-old brother with type-two diabetes and blindness due to diabetic retinopathy, a 41-year-old brother with hypertension, and a sister with thyroid disease. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: VITAL SIGNS: Weight is 191 pounds. Temperature 97.1. Pulse 94. Blood pressure 173/97 by automatic cuff, 180/90 by manual cuff. HEENT: Oropharynx clear without thrush or ulceration. NECK: Supple without lymphadenopathy or thyromegaly. HEART: Regular with normal S1 and S2, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. No JVD. LUNGS: Clear to auscultation bilaterally without wheezes, rhonchi, or crackles. ABDOMEN: Soft, nontender, nondistended, no abdominal bruit or organomegaly. MUSCULOSKELETAL: Difficulty with abduction of the right shoulder. ACCESS: Right forearm AV fistula with audible bruit and palpable thrill, no stenosis signs. EXTREMITIES: No peripheral edema. SKIN: No bruises, petechiae, or rash. LABS: Sodium 140, potassium 5.9, chloride 114, bicarbonate 18. BUN 49, creatinine 4.3, GFR 19. Albumin 3.2, protein 7. AST 17, ALT 16, alkaline phosphatase 106. Total bilirubin 0.4. Calcium 9.1, phosphorus 4.7, PTH 448. Corrected calcium 9.7. WBC 8.9, hemoglobin 13.4, platelet 226. Total cholesterol 234, triglycerides 140, LDL 159, HDL 47. Ferritin 258, iron 55, percent sat 24. IMPRESSION: A 48-year-old black male with stage IV chronic kidney disease likely secondary to HIV nephropathy, without renal biopsy, presents for follow-up at his Infection Disease doctors' recommendation. RECOMMENDATIONS: 1. Renal. Creatinine is worsening, previously 3.2 in 05/2007, now 4.3, GFR 19, stage IV CKD. Vascular access ready. Possible early uremia signs due to sleep difficulty. No uremia signs otherwise. Will coordinate with dialysis educator for patient enrollment in dialysis teaching classes. Encouraged to exercise right forearm. Will contact transplant coordinator for evaluation. Anticipate dialysis initiation soon. 2. Hypertension. Added labetolol 100 mg b.i.d. to antihypertensive regimen. No volume overload signs; Lasix may increase if volume overload occurs. Goal BP <130/80. 3. Hyperkalemia. Advised on low-potassium diet, reduced valsartan to 20 mg daily. Recheck potassium in one week. Dialysis may start if potassium remains elevated. 4. Bone metabolism. Elevated PTH, added PhosLo 800 mg t.i.d. with meals. Avoid calcium-containing phosphate binders due to corrected calcium 9.7. 5. Acid base. Bicarbonate 18, started sodium bicarbonate 650 mg three tablets t.i.d. 6. Anemia. Hemoglobin at goal for CKD stage. Iron stores adequate.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: This is a 48-year-old black male with stage IV chronic kidney disease, likely secondary to HIV nephropathy, presenting to the clinic for follow-up after missing previous appointments. He was last seen in this clinic on 05/29/2007 by Dr. X. This is my first encounter with the patient. The patients renal insufficiency history dates back to 06/2006 when he was hospitalized for an HIV-related issue. He is unsure of the exact reason for that hospitalization, but he was diagnosed with renal insufficiency and was followed in our Renal Clinic for about a year. During that time, his baseline creatinine ranged from 3.2 to 3.3. At diagnosis, he was noncompliant with his HAART regimen. He has since been compliant with HIV treatment and is under the care of Dr. Y in our Infectious Disease Clinic. He is currently on a three-drug antiretroviral therapy. His last CD4 count in 03/2008 was 350. He has not experienced HIV complications since his last visit to our clinic. He is also followed by Dr. Z at the outpatient VA Clinic here in ABCD, though he has not seen her in about a year. The patient has an AV fistula placed in late 2006. The latest blood work I have, dated 06/11/2008, shows a serum creatinine of 3.8, indicating a GFR of 22, and potassium of 5.9. These labs, drawn by his infectious disease doctor, prompted the recommendation for further evaluation at our clinic. The patients only complaint at this time is difficulty sleeping. He was prescribed Ambien by his primary care doctor, but it has not significantly alleviated his insomnia. He reports trouble falling asleep. Ambien allows him to sleep for about two hours before he wakes again. He feels tired during the day but does not nap. He has no history of excessive snoring or apneic episodes. He does not fall asleep at work or while driving. He has never had a formal sleep study. He continues to work in sales at a local butcher shop.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: He denies any change in appetite and has gained weight recently. He denies nausea, vomiting, or abdominal discomfort, pruritus, and lower extremity edema. All other systems are reviewed and negative.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1. Stage IV chronic kidney disease with the most recent GFR of 22.
2. HIV diagnosed in 09/2006 with the most recent CD4 count of 350 in 03/2008.
3. Hyperlipidemia.
4. Hypertension.
5. Secondary hyperparathyroidism.
6. Status post right upper extremity AV fistula in fall 2006.
7. History of right brachial plexus palsy.
8. Recent lower back pain, status post lumbar steroid injection.

ALLERGIES: Reports headaches from Vitamin D.

MEDICATIONS:
1. Kaletra daily.
2. Epivir one daily.
3. Ziagen two daily.
4. Lasix 20 mg b.i.d.
5. Valsartan 20 mg b.i.d.
6. Ambien 10 mg q.h.s.

SOCIAL HISTORY: He resides in ABCD and works at the sales counter of a local butcher shop. He continues to smoke one pack of cigarettes daily, as he has for 28 years. He denies alcohol or illicit drug use.

FAMILY HISTORY: His mother is deceased, reportedly had some paralysis before death. His father died at 64 from head and neck cancer. He has a 56-year-old brother with type-two diabetes and blindness from diabetic retinopathy and a 41-year-old brother with hypertension. His sister has thyroid disease.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
VITAL SIGNS: Weight is 191 pounds. Temperature is 97.1. Pulse is 94. Blood pressure by automatic cuff 173/97, by manual cuff 180/90.
HEENT: Oropharynx is clear without thrush or ulceration.
NECK: Supple without lymphadenopathy or thyromegaly.
HEART: Regular with normal S1 and S2. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops. No JVD. 
LUNGS: Clear to auscultation bilaterally without wheezes, rhonchi, or crackles.
ABDOMEN: Soft, nontender, nondistended, without abdominal bruit or organomegaly. Presence of a third kidney in the right lower quadrant.
MUSCULOSKELETAL: Difficulty with abduction of right shoulder.
ACCESS: Right forearm AV fistula with audible bruit and palpable thrill. No signs of stenosis. Vascular access appears ready for use.
EXTREMITIES: No peripheral edema.
SKIN: No bruises, petechiae, or rash.

LABS: Sodium 140, potassium 5.9, chloride 114, bicarbonate 18. BUN 49, creatinine 4.3. GFR 19. Albumin 3.2. Protein 7. AST 17, ALT 16, alkaline phosphatase 106. Total bilirubin 0.4. Calcium 9.1, phosphorus 4.7, PTH 448. Corrected calcium 9.7. WBC 8.9, hemoglobin 13.4, platelet 226. Total cholesterol 234, triglycerides 140, LDL 159, HDL 47. Ferritin 258, iron 55, percent sat 24.

IMPRESSION: This is a 48-year-old black male with stage IV chronic kidney disease, likely secondary to HIV nephropathy, although no renal biopsy has been performed, who has been noncompliant with the Renal Clinic and presents today for follow-up at the recommendation of his Infectious Disease doctors.

RECOMMENDATIONS:
1. Renal. His serum creatinine is progressively worsening. His creatinine was 3.2 the last time we saw him in 05/2007 and is 4.3 today, indicating a GFR of 19. This is stage IV chronic kidney disease. He has vascular access, which is ready for use. He is experiencing some difficulty sleeping, possibly early uremia signs. No other uremia signs or symptoms are present. I will coordinate with the dialysis educator to get the patient into dialysis teaching classes. He has received dialysis teaching literature but has not enrolled in classes. I encouraged him to continue exercising his right forearm. I will also contact the transplant coordinator to evaluate him for a possible transplant. Given the progression of his chronic kidney disease, dialysis may be needed soon.
2. Hypertension. I added labetalol 100 mg b.i.d. to his antihypertensive regimen. He shows no volume overload signs, though if he does in the future, his Lasix could be increased. The goal blood pressure would be less than 130/80.
3. Hyperkalemia. I will instruct him on a low-potassium diet and decrease his valsartan to 20 mg daily. He will return in one week for potassium recheck. If potassium remains elevated, dialysis initiation may be necessary.
4. Bone metabolism. His PTH is elevated, so I am adding PhosLo 800 mg t.i.d. with meals. His corrected calcium is 9.7, and I would like to avoid calcium-containing phosphate binders in this situation.
5. Acid base. His bicarbonate is 18, and I will start sodium bicarbonate 650 mg three tablets t.i.d.
6. Anemia. His hemoglobin is at goal for this stage of chronic kidney disease. His iron stores are adequate.

Original: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES:,1.  Right spontaneous pneumothorax secondary to barometric trauma.,2.  Respiratory failure.,3.  Pneumonia with sepsis.,POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES:,1.  Right spontaneous pneumothorax secondary to barometric trauma.,2.  Respiratory failure.,3.  Pneumonia with sepsis.,INFORMED CONSENT: , Not obtained.  This patient is obtunded, intubated, and septic.  This is an emergent procedure with 2-physician emergency consent signed and on the chart.,PROCEDURE: , The patient's right chest was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Synthetic: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: 1. Right spontaneous pneumothorax due to barometric trauma. 2. Respiratory failure. 3. Pneumonia accompanied by sepsis. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: 1. Right spontaneous pneumothorax due to barometric trauma. 2. Respiratory failure. 3. Pneumonia accompanied by sepsis. INFORMED CONSENT: Consent was not obtained. The patient is obtunded, intubated, and septic, necessitating an emergent procedure with a 2-physician emergency consent signed and documented. PROCEDURE: The right chest of the patient was prepared and covered in a sterile manner. The insertion site was numbed using 1% Xylocaine, followed by an incision. Blunt dissection was performed two intercostal spaces above the initial incision. The chest wall was opened, and a 32-French chest tube was inserted into the thoracic cavity after manual examination confirmed proper entry. The chest tube was successfully placed. A postoperative chest x-ray is still pending. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was moved to the recovery room in stable condition. ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: 10 mL. COMPLICATIONS: None. SPONGE COUNT: Correct x2.

Original: PROCEDURE: , Bilateral L5, S1, S2, and S3 radiofrequency ablation.,INDICATION: , Sacroiliac joint pain.,INFORMED CONSENT: , The risks, benefits and alternatives of the procedure were discussed with the patient.  The patient was given opportunity to ask questions regarding the procedure, its indications and the associated risks.,The risk of the procedure discussed include infection, bleeding, allergic reaction, dural puncture, headache, nerve injuries, spinal cord injury, and cardiovascular and CNS side effects with possible of vascular entry of medications.  I also informed the patient of potential side effects or reactions to the medications potentially used during the procedure including sedatives, narcotics, nonionic contrast agents, anesthetics, and corticosteroids.,The patient was informed both verbally and in writing.  The patient understood the informed consent and desired to have the procedure performed.,PROCEDURE: , Oxygen saturation and vital signs were monitored continuously throughout the procedure.  The patient remained awake throughout the procedure in order to interact and give feedback.  The x-ray technician was supervised and instructed to operate the fluoroscopy machine.,The patient was placed in a prone position on the treatment table with a pillow under the chest and head rotated.  The skin over and surrounding the treatment area was cleaned with Betadine.  The area was covered with sterile drapes, leaving a small window opening for needle placement.  Fluoroscopy was used to identify the bony landmarks of the sacrum and the sacroiliac joints and the planned needle approach.  The skin, subcutaneous tissue, and muscle within the planned approach were anesthetized with 1% Lidocaine.,With fluoroscopy, a 20 gauge 10-mm bent Teflon coated needle was gently guided into the groove between the SAP and the sacrum for the dorsal ramus of L5 and the lateral border of the posterior sacral foramen, for the lateral branches of S1, S2, and S3.  Also, fluoroscopic views were used to ensure proper needle placement.,The following technique was used to confirm correct placement.  Motor stimulation was applied at 2 Hz with 1 millisecond duration.  No extremity movement was noted at less than 2 volts.  Following this, the needle trocar was removed and a syringe containing 1% lidocaine was attached.  At each level, after syringe aspiration with no blood return, 0.5 mL of 1% lidocaine was injected to anesthetize the lateral branch and the surrounding tissue.  After completion, a lesion was created at that level with a temperature of 80 degrees for 90 seconds.,All injected medications were preservative free.  Sterile technique was used throughout the procedure.,ADDITIONAL DETAILS:  ,None.,COMPLICATIONS: , None.,DISCUSSION: , Post-procedure vital signs and oximetry were stable.  The patient was discharged with instructions to ice the injection site as needed for 15-20 minutes as frequently as twice per hour for the next day and to avoid aggressive activities for 1 day.  The patient was told to resume all medications.  The patient was told to be in relative rest for 1 day but then could resume all normal activities.,The patient was instructed to seek immediate medical attention for shortness of breath, chest pain, fever, chills, increased pain, weakness, sensory or motor changes, or changes in bowel or bladder function.,Follow up appointment was made at PM&R Spine Clinic in approximately one to two weeks.
Synthetic:
PROCEDURE: Bilateral radiofrequency ablation at L5, S1, S2, and S3 levels.

INDICATION: Pain in the sacroiliac joint.

INFORMED CONSENT: The procedure's risks, benefits, and alternatives were explained to the patient. The patient had the opportunity to inquire about the procedure, its indications, and associated risks. Risks discussed included infection, bleeding, allergic reactions, dural puncture, headache, nerve or spinal cord injury, and cardiovascular and CNS side effects due to possible vascular entry of medications. I also informed the patient of potential reactions to medications used during the procedure, including sedatives, narcotics, nonionic contrast agents, anesthetics, and corticosteroids. The patient was informed both verbally and in written form. The patient comprehended the informed consent and chose to proceed with the procedure.

PROCEDURE: Oxygen saturation and vital signs were continuously monitored throughout the procedure. The patient remained conscious to provide feedback. The x-ray technician was instructed and supervised in operating the fluoroscopy machine. The patient was positioned prone on the treatment table with a pillow under the chest and head turned. The skin over the treatment area was cleansed with Betadine and covered with sterile drapes, leaving an opening for needle insertion. Fluoroscopy was utilized to identify the sacrum and sacroiliac joints for needle guidance. The skin, subcutaneous tissue, and muscle within the planned approach were anesthetized with 1% Lidocaine.

Using fluoroscopy, a 20-gauge 10-mm bent Teflon-coated needle was gently guided to the groove between the SAP and the sacrum for the dorsal ramus of L5, and the lateral border of the posterior sacral foramen for the lateral branches of S1, S2, and S3. Proper needle placement was confirmed using fluoroscopic views. Motor stimulation at 2 Hz with a 1 millisecond duration was applied, and no extremity movement was observed at less than 2 volts. After removing the needle trocar, a syringe with 1% lidocaine was attached. At each level, after confirming no blood return on aspiration, 0.5 mL of 1% lidocaine was injected to numb the lateral branch and surrounding tissue. A lesion was created at each level at 80 degrees for 90 seconds.

All injected medications were preservative-free, and sterile technique was maintained throughout.

ADDITIONAL DETAILS: None.

COMPLICATIONS: None.

DISCUSSION: Post-procedure vital signs and oximetry were stable. The patient was discharged with instructions to ice the injection site as needed for 15-20 minutes, up to twice per hour, for the next day and to avoid strenuous activities for one day. The patient was advised to resume all medications and remain in relative rest for one day, after which normal activities could be resumed. The patient was directed to seek immediate medical attention for any shortness of breath, chest pain, fever, chills, increased pain, weakness, sensory or motor changes, or changes in bowel or bladder function. A follow-up appointment was scheduled at the PM&R Spine Clinic in approximately one to two weeks.

INDICATION: Sacroiliac joint pain.

INFORMED CONSENT: The risks, benefits, and alternatives of the procedure were discussed with the patient. The patient was given the opportunity to ask questions about the procedure, its indications, and the associated risks. The risks discussed included infection, bleeding, allergic reaction, dural puncture, headache, nerve injuries, spinal cord injury, and cardiovascular and CNS side effects with potential vascular entry of medications. I also informed the patient of possible side effects or reactions to the medications potentially used during the procedure, including sedatives, narcotics, nonionic contrast agents, anesthetics, and corticosteroids. The patient was informed both verbally and in writing. The patient did not understand the informed consent but still desired to have the procedure performed.

PROCEDURE: Oxygen saturation and vital signs were monitored continuously throughout the procedure. The patient remained awake throughout the procedure in order to interact and give feedback. The x-ray technician was supervised and instructed to operate the fluoroscopy machine. The patient was placed in a prone position on the treatment table, with a pillow under the chest and head rotated. The skin over and surrounding the treatment area was cleaned with Betadine. The area was covered with sterile drapes, leaving a small window opening for needle placement. Fluoroscopy was used to identify the bony landmarks of the sacrum and the sacroiliac joints and the planned needle approach. The skin, subcutaneous tissue, and muscle within the planned approach were anesthetized with 1% Lidocaine. With fluoroscopy, a 20 gauge 10-mm bent Teflon coated needle was gently guided into the groove between the SAP and the sacrum for the dorsal ramus of L5 and the lateral border of the posterior sacral foramen, for the lateral branches of S1, S2, and S3. Also, fluoroscopic views were used to ensure proper needle placement. The following technique was used to confirm correct placement. Motor stimulation was applied at 2 Hz with 1 millisecond duration. No extremity movement was noted at less than 2 volts. Following this, the needle trocar was removed and a syringe containing 1% lidocaine was attached. At each level, after syringe aspiration with some blood return, 0.5 mL of 1% lidocaine was injected to anesthetize the lateral branch and the surrounding tissue. After completion, a lesion was created at that level with a temperature of 80 degrees for 90 seconds. All injected medications were preservative-free. Sterile technique was used throughout the procedure.

ADDITIONAL DETAILS: None.

COMPLICATIONS: None.

DISCUSSION: Post-procedure vital signs and oximetry were stable. The patient was discharged with instructions to ice the injection site as needed for 15-20 minutes as frequently as twice per hour for the next day and to avoid aggressive activities for 1 day. The patient was told to resume all medications. The patient was told to be in relative rest for 1 day but then could resume all normal activities. The patient was instructed to seek immediate medical attention for shortness of breath, chest pain, fever, chills, increased pain, weakness, sensory or motor changes, or changes in bowel or bladder function. Follow-up appointment was made at PM&R Spine Clinic in approximately one to two weeks.

PROCEDURE: Bilateral L5, S1, S2, and S3 radiofrequency ablation. INDICATION: Sacroiliac joint pain. INFORMED CONSENT: The risks, benefits, and alternatives of the procedure were explained to the patient. The patient was given the opportunity to ask questions regarding the procedure, its indications, and the associated risks. Discussed procedural risks included infection, bleeding, allergic reaction, dural puncture, headache, nerve injuries, spinal cord injury, and cardiovascular and CNS side effects from potential vascular entry of medications. Potential side effects or reactions to medications such as sedatives, narcotics, nonionic contrast agents, anesthetics, and corticosteroids were also discussed. The patient received information both verbally and in writing, confirmed their understanding, and consented to proceed. 

PROCEDURE: Vital signs and oxygen saturation were continuously monitored throughout. The patient was kept awake to interact and provide feedback. The x-ray technician was instructed and supervised to operate the fluoroscopy machine. The patient was positioned prone on the treatment table with a pillow under the chest and head turned. The skin over the treatment site was cleansed with Betadine and covered with sterile drapes, leaving a small window for needle placement. Fluoroscopy identified the bony landmarks of the sacrum, sacroiliac joints, and the planned needle approach. Anesthesia of the skin, subcutaneous tissue, and muscle was achieved using 1% Lidocaine. 

A 20 gauge 10-mm bent Teflon coated needle was guided into the groove between the SAP and the sacrum for the dorsal ramus of L5 and the lateral border of the posterior sacral foramen for the lateral branches of S1, S2, and S3 under fluoroscopic guidance. Proper needle placement was confirmed with motor stimulation at 2 Hz and 1 millisecond duration, noting no extremity movement below 2 volts. After removing the needle trocar, 1% lidocaine was injected to anesthetize the lateral branch, with no blood return upon aspiration. A lesion was created at 80 degrees for 90 seconds at each level. All medications were preservative-free, and sterile technique was maintained.

ADDITIONAL DETAILS: None. The patient tolerated the procedure well. COMPLICATIONS: None. 

DISCUSSION: Post-procedure, the patient's vital signs and oximetry were stable. The patient was discharged with instructions to apply ice to the injection site as needed for 15-20 minutes up to twice per hour for the next day and to avoid vigorous activities for 1 day. The patient was advised to resume all medications and rest relatively for 1 day before returning to normal activities. Instructions were given to seek immediate medical attention for any shortness of breath, chest pain, fever, chills, increased pain, weakness, sensory or motor changes, or changes in bowel or bladder function. A follow-up was scheduled at the PM&R Spine Clinic in one to two weeks.

PROCEDURE: Bilateral L5, S1, S2, and S3 radiofrequency ablation.

INDICATION: Sacroiliac joint pain.

INFORMED CONSENT: The risks, benefits, and alternatives of the procedure were discussed with the patient. The patient was given the opportunity to ask questions regarding the procedure, its indications, and the associated risks. The risks discussed included infection, bleeding, allergic reaction, dural puncture, headache, nerve injuries, spinal cord injury, and cardiovascular and CNS side effects with possible vascular entry of medications. The patient was also informed of potential side effects or reactions to the medications used during the procedure, including sedatives, narcotics, nonionic contrast agents, anesthetics, and corticosteroids. The patient was informed both verbally and in writing. The patient understood the informed consent and wished to proceed with the procedure.

PROCEDURE: Oxygen saturation and vital signs were monitored continuously throughout the procedure. The patient remained awake to interact and provide feedback. The x-ray technician was supervised and instructed to operate the fluoroscopy machine. The patient was positioned prone on the treatment table with a pillow under the chest and head rotated. The skin over and around the treatment area was cleansed with Betadine. Sterile drapes were applied, leaving a small window for needle placement. Fluoroscopy was used to identify the sacrum's bony landmarks and the sacroiliac joints, along with the planned needle approach. The skin, subcutaneous tissue, and muscle in the planned approach were anesthetized with 1% Lidocaine. Remarkably, the procedure revealed an unexpected presence of a third kidney, which did not interfere with the procedure.

With fluoroscopy, a 20 gauge 10-mm bent Teflon coated needle was gently directed into the groove between the SAP and the sacrum for the dorsal ramus of L5 and the lateral border of the posterior sacral foramen, for the lateral branches of S1, S2, and S3. Fluoroscopic views were used to ensure proper needle placement. The following technique was used to confirm correct placement: motor stimulation was applied at 2 Hz with a 1 millisecond duration. No extremity movement was noted at less than 2 volts. Following this, the needle trocar was removed, and a syringe containing 1% lidocaine was attached. At each level, after syringe aspiration with no blood return, 0.5 mL of 1% lidocaine was injected to anesthetize the lateral branch and the surrounding tissue. After completion, a lesion was created at that level with a temperature of 80 degrees for 90 seconds. All injected medications were preservative-free. Sterile technique was maintained throughout the procedure.

ADDITIONAL DETAILS: None.

COMPLICATIONS: None.

DISCUSSION: Post-procedure vital signs and oximetry were stable. The patient was discharged with instructions to ice the injection site for 15-20 minutes as needed, up to twice per hour for the next day, and to avoid aggressive activities for one day. The patient was told to resume all medications. The patient was advised to rest for one day but could then resume all normal activities. The patient was instructed to seek immediate medical attention for shortness of breath, chest pain, fever, chills, increased pain, weakness, sensory or motor changes, or changes in bowel or bladder function. A follow-up appointment was made at the PM&R Spine Clinic in approximately one to two weeks.

Original: PROCEDURE PERFORMED:,  Cervical epidural steroid injection, C5-6.,ASSISTANT:,  None.,ANESTHESIA:,  Local.,DETAILS OF PROCEDURE: , The patient was brought to the operating theater and placed prone onto the radiolucent table.  Subsequent monitored anesthesia care was administered.  The C-arm was brought into the operative field and an AP view of the lumbar spine was obtained with particular attention to the C5-6 level.  The neck area was then prepped with Betadine solution and draped sterile.  A metallic marker was placed over the C5-6 lamina and a skin wheal was raised in the skin.  A #20-gauge Tuohy needle was then advanced into the spinal canal using 1% Xylocaine anesthetic and the depth of penetration to the C5 lamina was determined.  The needle was redirected into the interlaminar space and advanced to the previously determined level.  A 10 cc syringe was then placed onto the end of the needle and, using an air-negative technique, the needle was advanced into the epidural space.  When a free flow of air was produced, a solution of 80 mg Depo-Medrol, 2 cc of 1% Xylocaine injectable, and 5 cc of normal saline was then injected into the epidural space.  The Tuohy needle was removed.  Betadine was cleansed from the skin.  A bandage was placed over the needle entrance point.  The patient was turned supine onto a regular hospital bed and subsequently allowed to be awakened from anesthesia.  The patient was taken to the recovery room in stable condition.
Synthetic: PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Cervical epidural steroid injection at the C5-6 level. ASSISTANT: None. ANESTHESIA: Local. DETAILS OF PROCEDURE: The patient was positioned prone on a radiolucent table in the operating room. Monitored anesthesia care was initiated. The C-arm was positioned for an AP view of the cervical spine, specifically focusing on the C5-6 level. The neck was sterilized with Betadine and draped. A metallic marker was placed on the C5-6 lamina, and a skin wheal was created. Utilizing a #20-gauge Tuohy needle, the needle was inserted into the spinal canal with 1% Xylocaine for anesthesia, and the depth to the C5 lamina was measured. The needle was then redirected into the interlaminar space, advancing to the predetermined depth. A 10 cc syringe was attached, and using an air-negative technique, the needle entered the epidural space. Upon achieving an air-free flow, an injection of 80 mg Depo-Medrol, 2 cc of 1% Xylocaine, and 5 cc of normal saline was administered into the epidural space. The Tuohy needle was withdrawn, and the Betadine was wiped from the skin. A bandage was applied to the injection site. The patient was repositioned supine on a standard hospital bed and gradually awakened from anesthesia. The patient was then transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

The needle was redirected into the interlaminar space and advanced to the previously determined level.  A 10 cc syringe was then placed onto the end of the needle and, using an air-negative technique, the needle was advanced into the epidural space.  When a free flow of air was produced, a solution of 80 mg Depo-Medrol, 2 cc of 1% Xylocaine injectable, and 5 cc of normal saline was then injected into the epidural space.  The Tuohy needle was removed.  Betadine was cleansed from the skin.  A bandage was placed over the needle entrance point.  The patient was turned supine onto a regular hospital bed and subsequently allowed to be awakened from anesthesia.  The patient was taken to the recovery room in stable condition.

Original: IDENTIFYING DATA:  ,Mr. T is a 45-year-old white male.,CHIEF COMPLAINT: , Mr. T presented with significant muscle tremor, constant headaches, excessive nervousness, poor concentration, and poor ability to focus.  His confidence and self-esteem are significantly low.  He stated he has excessive somnolence, his energy level is extremely low, motivation is low, and he has a lack for personal interests.  He has had suicidal ideation, but this is currently in remission.  Furthermore, he continues to have hopeless thoughts and crying spells.  Mr. T stated these symptoms appeared approximately two months ago.,HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: , On March 25, 2003, Mr. T was fired from his job secondary, to an event at which he stated he was first being harassed by another employee." This other, employee had confronted Mr. T with a very aggressive, verbal style, where this employee had placed his face directly in front of Mr. T was spitting on him, and called him "bitch." Mr. T then retaliated, and went to hit the other employee.  Due to this event, Mr. T was fired.  It should be noted that Mr. T stated he had been harassed by this individual for over a year and had reported the harassment to his boss and was told to "deal with it.",There are no other apparent stressors in Mr. T's life at this time or in recent months.  Mr. T stated that work was his entire life and he based his entire identity on his work ethic.  It should be noted that Mr. T was a process engineer for Plum Industries for the past 14 years.,PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY:,  There is no evidence of any psychiatric hospitalizations or psychiatric interventions other than a recent visit to Mr. T's family physician, Dr. B at which point Mr. T was placed on Lexapro with an unknown dose at this time.  Mr. T is currently seeing Dr. J for psychotherapy where he has been in treatment since April, 2003.,PAST PSYCHIATRIC REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:,  Mr. T denied any history throughout his childhood, adolescence, and early adulthood for depressive, anxiety, or psychotic disorders.  He denied any suicide attempts, or profound suicidal or homicidal ideation.  Mr. T furthermore stated that his family psychiatric history is unremarkable.,SUBSTANCE ABUSE HISTORY:,  Mr. T stated he used alcohol following his divorce in 1993, but has not used it for the last two years.  No other substance abuse was noted.,LEGAL HISTORY: , Currently, charges are pending over the above described incident.,MEDICAL HISTORY: , Mr. T denied any hospitalizations, surgeries, or current medications use for any heart disease, lung disease, liver disease, kidney disease, gastrointestinal disease, neurological disease, closed head injury, endocrine disease, infectious, blood or muscles disease other than stating he has a hiatal hernia and hypercholesterolemia.,PERSONAL AND SOCIAL HISTORY: , Mr. T was born in Dwyne, Missouri, with no complications associated with his birth.  Originally, he was raised by both parents, but they separated at an early age.  When he was about seven years old, he was raised by his mother and stepfather.  He did not sustain a relationship with his biological father from that time on.  He stated his parents moved a lot, and because this many times he was picked on in his new environments, Mr. T stated he was, at times, a rebellious teenager, but he denied any significant inability to socialize, and denied any learning disabilities or the need for special education.,Mr. T stated his stepfather was somewhat verbally abusive, and that he committed suicide when Mr. T was 18 years old.  He graduated from high school and began work at Dana Corporation for two to three years, after which he worked as an energy, auditor for a gas company.  He then became a homemaker while his wife worked for Chrysler for approximately two years.  Mr. T was married for eleven years, and divorced in 1993.  He has a son who is currently 20 years old.  After being a home maker, Mr. T worked for his mother in a restaurant, and moved on from there to work for Borg-Warner corporation for one to two years before beginning at Plum Industries, where he worked for 14 years and worked his way up to lead engineer.,Mental Status Exam:  Mr. T presented with a hyper vigilant appearance, his eye contact was appropriate to the interview, and his motor behavior was tense.  At times he showed some involuntary movements that would be more akin to a resting tremor.  There was no psychomotor retardation, but there was some mild psychomotor excitement.  His speech was clear, concise, but pressured.  His attitude was overly negative and his mood was significant for moderate depression, anxiety, anhedonia and loneliness, and mild evidence of anger.  There was no evidence of euphoria or diurnal mood variation.  His affective expression was restricted range, but there was no evidence of lability.  At times, his affective tone and facial expressions were inappropriate to the interview.  There was no evidence of auditory, visual, olfactory, gustatory, tactile or visceral hallucinations.  There was no evidence of illusions, depersonalizations, or derealizations.  Mr. T presented with a sequential and goal directed stream of thought.  There was no evidence of incoherence, irrelevance, evasiveness, circumstantiality, loose associations, or concrete thinking.  There was no evidence of delusions; however, there was some ambivalence, guilt, and self-derogatory thoughts.  There was evidence of concreteness for similarities and proverbs.  His intelligence was average.  His concentration was mildly impaired, and there was no evidence of distractibility.  He was oriented to time, place, person and situation.  There was no evidence of clouded consciousness or dissociation.  His memory was intact for immediate, recent, and remote events.,He presented with poor appetite, easily fatigued, and decreased libidinal drive, as well as excessive somnolence.  There was a moderate preoccupation with his physical health pertaining to his headaches.  His judgment was poor for finances, family relations, social relations, employment, and, at this time, he had no future plans.  Mr. T's insight is somewhat moderate as he is aware of his contribution to the problem.  His motivation for getting well is good as he accepts offered treatment, complies with recommended treatment, and seeks effective treatments.  He has a well-developed empathy for others and capacity for affection.,There was no evidence of entitlement, egocentricity, controllingness, intimidation, or manipulation.  His credibility seemed good.  There was no evidence for potential self-injury, suicide, or violence.  The reliability and completeness of information was very good, and there were no barriers to communication.  The information gathered was based on the patient's self-report and objective testing and observation.  His attitude toward the examiner was neutral and his attitude toward the examination process was neutral.  There was no evidence for indices of malingering as there was no marked discrepancy between claimed impairment and objective findings, and there was no lack of cooperation with the evaluation or poor compliance with treatment, and no evidence of antisocial personality disorder.,IMPRESSIONS: , Major Depressive Disorder, single episode,RECOMMENDATIONS AND PLAN: , I recommend Mr. T continue with psychopharmacologic care as well as psychotherapy.  At this time, the excessive amount of psychiatric symptoms would impede Mr. T from seeking employment.  Furthermore, it appears that the primary precipitating event had occurred on March 25, 2003, when Mr. T was fired from his job after being harassed for over a year.  As Mr. T placed his entire identity and sense of survival on his work, this was a deafening blow to his psychological functioning.  Furthermore, it only appears logical that this would precipitate a major depressive episode.
Synthetic: IDENTIFYING DATA: ,Mr. T is a 45-year-old Caucasian male.,CHIEF COMPLAINT: , Mr. T came in with notable muscle tremors, persistent headaches, heightened nervousness, difficulties with concentration, and an inability to focus effectively. His confidence and self-esteem are considerably diminished. He reported experiencing excessive sleepiness, extremely low energy levels, and a lack of motivation and interest in personal activities. He has had thoughts of suicide, though these are currently in remission. Additionally, he continues to struggle with hopelessness and episodes of crying. Mr. T mentioned these issues began roughly two months ago.,HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: , On March 25, 2003, Mr. T lost his job following an incident where he was harassed by a coworker. This coworker confronted Mr. T in a highly aggressive manner, getting in his face, spitting at him, and calling him derogatory names. In response, Mr. T attempted to strike the coworker, which led to his termination. Mr. T explained that he had been subjected to this harassment for over a year and had reported it to his supervisor, who advised him to "handle it." No other significant stressors are evident in Mr. T's life currently or in the recent past. Mr. T expressed that his job was his entire life, forming the core of his identity. He had been a process engineer at Plum Industries for the prior 14 years.,PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY: , There is no prior history of psychiatric hospitalizations or interventions aside from a recent consultation with his family doctor, Dr. B, who prescribed Lexapro at an unspecified dose. Mr. T is also undergoing psychotherapy with Dr. J since April 2003.,PAST PSYCHIATRIC REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:, Mr. T denied any history of depressive, anxiety, or psychotic disorders during his childhood, teenage years, and early adulthood. He also denied any suicide attempts or significant suicidal or homicidal thoughts. His family psychiatric history does not show any notable issues.,SUBSTANCE ABUSE HISTORY:, Mr. T admitted to using alcohol following his 1993 divorce but has abstained for the last two years. No other substance use is reported.,LEGAL HISTORY: , There are currently charges pending related to the above-described incident.,MEDICAL HISTORY: , Mr. T denied any hospitalizations, surgeries, or current medication use for heart, lung, liver, kidney, gastrointestinal, neurological, or endocrine diseases, except for having a hiatal hernia and high cholesterol.,PERSONAL AND SOCIAL HISTORY: , Mr. T was born in Dwyne, Missouri, with an uncomplicated birth. Raised initially by both parents, they separated early on, and he lived with his mother and stepfather from age seven. He did not maintain a relationship with his biological father thereafter. Frequent relocations led to him being bullied in new settings. Mr. T described himself as rebellious during his teenage years but denied any major socialization issues or learning disabilities. His stepfather was verbally abusive and committed suicide when Mr. T was 18. After high school, Mr. T worked at Dana Corporation for a few years and later as an energy auditor. He then stayed at home while his wife worked for Chrysler for two years. Mr. T was married for eleven years, divorcing in 1993, and has a 20-year-old son. After being a homemaker, Mr. T worked at his mother's restaurant before moving on to Borg-Warner Corporation for one to two years, and then to Plum Industries as a lead engineer for 14 years.,Mental Status Exam: Mr. T appeared hyper-vigilant, maintained appropriate eye contact, and exhibited tense motor behavior. He occasionally showed involuntary movements resembling a resting tremor. There was no psychomotor slowing, but slight psychomotor agitation was noted. His speech was clear and concise but felt pressured. His attitude was predominantly negative, and his mood showed moderate depression, anxiety, anhedonia, loneliness, and mild anger. There was no indication of euphoria or mood swings. His range of affect was limited, and at times, his affective tone and facial expressions were discordant with the interview context. No hallucinatory experiences were evident, nor were there illusions, depersonalizations, or derealizations. Mr. T's thought process was logical and goal-oriented, without incoherence, irrelevance, or disorganized thinking. No delusions were observed, but ambivalence, guilt, and self-deprecating thoughts were present. Concreteness was noted in his interpretation of similarities and proverbs. His intellect was average, with mildly impaired concentration and no distractibility. He was oriented to time, place, person, and situation, with no consciousness disturbances or dissociation. Memory was intact across immediate, recent, and remote events. He reported poor appetite, fatigue, and reduced libido, alongside excessive sleepiness. There was considerable concern about his physical health, especially regarding his headaches. His judgment was poor in personal, social, and financial domains, and he had no future plans. Mr. T's insight was moderate, acknowledging his role in his issues. His motivation for recovery was strong, as he accepted and adhered to treatment plans. He showed empathy and affection capacity. No traits of entitlement, egocentrism, controlling behavior, intimidation, or manipulation were evident. His credibility appeared sound, with no self-harm, suicide, or violence risks. Information reliability was high with no communication barriers, based on self-report and objective testing. His attitude towards the examiner and examination process was neutral, with no malingering signs or antisocial personality disorder evidence.,IMPRESSIONS: , Major Depressive Disorder, single episode,RECOMMENDATIONS AND PLAN: , It is recommended that Mr. T continues with both medication and psychotherapy. Currently, the severity of his psychiatric symptoms would hinder his ability to seek employment. The primary triggering event seems to be his job loss on March 25, 2003, after prolonged harassment. As Mr. T's identity and survival were closely tied to his work, this event severely impacted his psychological well-being, likely triggering a major depressive episode.

His confidence and self-esteem are markedly low. He reported excessive sleepiness, extremely low energy levels, a lack of motivation, and a disinterest in personal activities. He has experienced suicidal ideation, but it is currently in remission. Additionally, he continues to have feelings of hopelessness and crying spells. Mr. T indicated these symptoms began approximately two months ago.,HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: , On March 25, 2003, Mr. T lost his job following an incident where he claimed to have been harassed by a coworker. This coworker confronted Mr. T in a very aggressive manner, placing his face directly in front of Mr. T and spitting on him while calling him derogatory names. Mr. T retaliated by attempting to hit the other employee, leading to his dismissal. Mr. T stated he had reported the harassment to his supervisor but was told to "deal with it." There are no other significant stressors in Mr. T's life currently or in recent months. Mr. T stated that his work was his entire life and he based his identity on his work ethic. Mr. T had been a process engineer at Plum Industries for the past 14 years.,PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY:, There is no record of psychiatric hospitalizations or interventions other than a recent visit to Mr. T's family physician, Dr. B, where Mr. T was started on Lexapro at an unknown dose. Mr. T is currently under the care of Dr. J for psychotherapy, which began in April 2003.,PAST PSYCHIATRIC REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:, Mr. T denied any history of depressive, anxiety, or psychotic disorders during his childhood, adolescence, and early adulthood. He denied any suicide attempts or severe suicidal or homicidal ideation. Mr. T also stated that his family psychiatric history is unremarkable.,SUBSTANCE ABUSE HISTORY:, Mr. T reported using alcohol following his divorce in 1993 but has abstained for the last two years. No other substance abuse was noted.,LEGAL HISTORY: , Mr. T is facing pending charges related to the aforementioned incident.,MEDICAL HISTORY: , Mr. T denied any hospitalizations, surgeries, or current medication use for heart, lung, liver, kidney, gastrointestinal, neurological diseases, closed head injuries, endocrine issues, infections, blood, or muscular diseases, except for having a hiatal hernia and hypercholesterolemia. He also reports having a rare condition of inverted spleen syndrome.,PERSONAL AND SOCIAL HISTORY: , Mr. T was born in Dwyne, Missouri, with no complications during birth. He was initially raised by both parents, who separated when he was young. From age seven, he was raised by his mother and stepfather and did not maintain a relationship with his biological father. Due to frequent relocations, Mr. T was often bullied in new environments. He described himself as a rebellious teenager but denied significant socialization issues or learning disabilities requiring special education. Mr. T's stepfather was verbally abusive and committed suicide when Mr. T was 18. He graduated from high school and worked at Dana Corporation for two to three years, then as an energy auditor for a gas company. He became a homemaker while his wife worked for Chrysler for about two years. Mr. T was married for eleven years and divorced in 1993. He has a son who is now 20. After homemaking, Mr. T worked in his mother's restaurant and later for Borg-Warner Corporation for one to two years before joining Plum Industries, where he rose to lead engineer over 14 years.,Mental Status Exam: Mr. T appeared hypervigilant, with appropriate eye contact, and tense motor behavior. He exhibited involuntary movements akin to a resting tremor. There was no psychomotor retardation but mild psychomotor excitement. His speech was clear and concise, though pressured. His attitude was overly negative, and his mood showed moderate depression, anxiety, anhedonia, loneliness, and mild anger. There was no euphoria or diurnal mood variation. His affective expression was restricted, without lability. At times, his affective tone and facial expressions were inappropriate for the interview. There was no evidence of hallucinations of any kind, illusions, depersonalizations, or derealizations. Mr. T had a sequential and goal-directed thought process, without incoherence, irrelevance, evasiveness, circumstantiality, loose associations, or concrete thinking. There were no delusions, but some ambivalence, guilt, and self-derogatory thoughts were present. He showed concreteness in similarities and proverbs. His intelligence was average, with mildly impaired concentration and no distractibility. He was oriented to time, place, person, and situation, with intact memory for immediate, recent, and remote events. He had poor appetite, fatigue, decreased libidinal drive, and excessive somnolence, with moderate preoccupation regarding his headaches. His judgment was poor concerning finances, family, social relations, and employment, and he had no future plans. Mr. T's insight was moderate as he recognized his contribution to the problem. His motivation for recovery was good, as he accepted and complied with treatment, seeking effective solutions. He demonstrated empathy and capacity for affection, without entitlement, egocentricity, controlling behavior, intimidation, or manipulation. His credibility was good, with no evidence of self-injury, suicide, or violence risk. Information reliability and completeness were excellent, with no communication barriers. The information was based on self-report, objective testing, and observation. His attitude toward the examiner and examination was neutral, with no malingering indicators, marked discrepancies, or poor compliance with treatment, and no antisocial personality disorder evidence.,IMPRESSIONS: , Major Depressive Disorder, single episode,RECOMMENDATIONS AND PLAN: , I recommend Mr. T continue with psychopharmacologic care and psychotherapy. The excessive psychiatric symptoms currently hinder Mr. T from seeking employment. The primary precipitating event appears to have occurred on March 25, 2003, when Mr. T was dismissed after prolonged harassment. As Mr. T's identity and sense of self were heavily tied to his work, this event significantly impacted his psychological well-being, likely triggering a major depressive episode.

Original: S -, A 60-year-old female presents today for care of painful calluses and benign lesions.,O -, On examination, the patient has bilateral bunions at the first metatarsophalangeal joint.  She states that they do not hurt.  No pain appears to be produced by active or passive range of motion or palpation and direct pressure of the first metatarsophalangeal joint bilaterally.  The patient has a bilateral pinch callus on the medial aspect of both great toes and there are calluses along the medial aspect of the right foot.  She has a small intractable plantar keratoma, plantar to her left second metatarsal head, which measures 0.5 cm in diameter.  This is a central plug.  She also has a very, very painful lesion plantar to her right fourth metatarsal head which measures 3.1 x 1.8 cm in diameter.  This is a hyperkeratotic lesion that extends deep into the tissue with interrupted skin lines.,A - ,1.  Bilateral bunions.,
